Mis ventas mejoraran mas si puedo obtener capital para invertir y poder comprar ropa variada.

loans.use: To buy children's, women's, and men's clothes

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en:
I sell soft drinks, juice, candy, churros, and fruit to people who walk past my small food cart on the street. Right now I need to buy more supplies to fill my cart so that I can increase my revenue and be better able to help my family.

Translated from Spanish by Alison Rives, Kiva Volunteer.

Tengo una pequeña carreta en la que vendo refrescos, jugos, dulces, churros y frutas a todas las personas que pasan por esta calle. Ahora necesito abastecer mi carreta para poder mejorar mis ingresos y poder ayudar mas a mi familia.

loans.use: To buy candy, churros, water, soft drinks, fruit, and other food

loans.name: Rosibel

texts.en:
My business is located near the public hospital in my country. Many people go to this hospital which helps me sell more in order to support my family. I now need to buy a greater variety of high-quality food so that I can increase my income even more.

Translated from Spanish by Alison Rives, Kiva Volunteer.

Mi negocio esta ubicado cerca del hospital publico de mi pais, y es bastante las personas que lo visitan, lo que me ayuda a tener buenas ventas para apoyar a mi familia. Ahora necesito surtir mi negocio con producto de calidad, variado y bueno para poder mejorar mis ingresos aun mas.

loans.use: To buy candy, churros, water, soft drinks, and other food

loans.name: Tula De Jesus

texts.en:
My name is Tula, and I sell food. I sell from Monday to Friday to clients who are visiting their families in this area of the capital. I need to supply my business with food so that I can increase my sales.

Translated from Spanish by Alison Rives, Kiva Volunteer.

Mi nombre es Tula y me dedico a la venta de comidas a personas que lo pidan, mis ventas las hago de lunes a viernes y mis clientes son personas que visitan a sus familiales en esta zona de la capital. Necesito surtir mi negocio con alimentos para mejorar mis ventas.

loans.use: To buy tortillas, lard, soft drinks, chicken, vegetables, rice, beans, and other food items

loans.name: Yobani

texts.en:
I work making keys in one of the largest areas of the capital. I help people by unlocking their car door or by unlocking the door of their house. I now need to buy a small machine so that I can offer my clients better service and make higher-quality keys.

Translated from Spanish by Alison Rives, Kiva Volunteer.

Me dedico a la elaboracion de llaves, este negocio lo tengo en una de las colonias mas grandes de la ciudad, tambien hago trabajos a domicilio cuando las personas me requieren para abrir puertas de carros o casas. Ahora necesito comprar una pequeña maquina para brindar a mis clientes un mejor servicio y fabricar llaves de mejor calidad.

loans.use: To buy a copper machine to make keys

loans.name: Shahperai

texts.en:
Shahperai, who is 35 years old, lives in Kabul, Afghanistan, in a household of seven.

She has a small shop in the alley where her house is. During the time of the Taliban government she was not able to work outside so she worked at home with her children, weaving carpets. But this business did not cover her financial problems so she started a grocery shop and bought lots of materials. Right now she wants to take a 1st individual loan through AFSG to buy ghee, rice, milk, Pepsi, beans, jam, etc.

She believes that by taking more loans from AFSG she can increase her business.

loans.use: To buy materials for her shop

loans.name: Rahela

texts.en:
Rahela was born in 1958. She lives in a household of 8 in district 7 of Kabul, Afghanistan.

Rahela wants a loan to increase her stock of poultry and pet birds and to buy seeds for them. Due to bird flu she lost 30 hens and chickens and then she sold the rest because no-one could buys birds and chickens at that time.

Rahela took a 6th cycle loan from AFSG to buy a cart and materials for her son. She believes that if the disease will be completely removed from the country she will be able to start her lost business again with the help of her son.

loans.use: To buy more poultry and pet birds

texts.en:
Nazanen has 20 years' experience with poultry & animal husbandry. She started having poultry at the age of 20 when she lived with her father's family in the village.

Because of a lack of birds she took a loan through AFSG to buy seeds and chickens for her farm. She started her business by selling eggs but now she sells both the chicks and the eggs at the bazaar.

She believes that by borrowing a big amount she can buy sheep and birds to increase her business and find more income.

Farkhunda, daughter of Jan M., was born in 1978 in Kabul, Afghanistan. Her family includes 9 members and she is single and has a vegetable sales business. She lives in District 7 of Kabul and has been busy with her work for 10 years. She buys vegetables from the market, cleans them at home, and then sells them at the bazaar to earn some money and assist her family financially. She is in her 5th loan cycle and has made good use of her loans to develop her business.

loans.name: Mohammad Zaher

texts.en:
M. Zaher began his business in a small shop near his house selling vegetables and fresh fruits. Due to a lack of money he could not afford to buy vegetables , fresh fruits and other materials, so he decided to take a loan through AFSG to increase his business. With that he left his old shop and took a new shop in the market where he can sell more items and develop his business.

M. Zaher, who works 7 days a week, is happy that he can cover his family financially, and to be able to repay his AFSG loan.

loans.use: To buy fresh fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Shahrukh

texts.en: Shahrukh, son of Amanullah, is 29. He was born in Kabul, Afghanistan and currently lives in District 7 of Kabul. He is single and has the responsibility for 8 family members. To honour his responsibility he has a wood shop where he sells wood and earns income to fulfill the requirements of his family. He is in his 5th loan cycle and wants to buy more wood for his shop with the loan money.

loans.use: To buy wood for his shop

texts.en:
Bibi Hawa weaves carpets with her 3 children in her house. She learned the trade during the war when she was in her village - at that time everybody weaved carpets. She learned from one of her neighbours and then she taught her children.

Bibi Hawa is an uneducated women but she prefers her children to study and go school. She took a loan with the help of a loan officer and then boughtlots of materials for her business.

She works 7 days of the week to complete one carpet in a month, then her husband sells it in the market. Through this process she can make a good income.

Parwen, daughter of N. H., was born in Kabul, Afghanistan. Her family includes 6 members and she is single. She weaves carpets with her 2 sisters and has been busy with her carpet weaving work for 5 years. Due to a lack of materials she took a 1st cycle loan to buy thread, wood and other materials to increase her business and to earn some money and assist her family financially.

Zarmina, daughter of Juma K., was born in 1989 and now lives in District 2 of Kabul, Afghanistan. She is married to Mohammad Gul and has 9 family members. She buys fruits and vegetables from the market and sells them. She has finished 4 cycles and is now trying to take a 5th loan cycle. During the Taliban Government she had less opportunity to work but now she is able to assist her family in solving their financial problems. She is very happy with her loans and wants to go ahead with them to secure a better future.

Nafas Gul, daughter of Saifullah, was born in 1960 and currently lives in District 2 in Kabul, Afghanistan. She is married and has 10 family members. She has a tailoring business at her home through which she solves her financial problems. She has taken 4 loans and now wants to take a 5th cycle. In her previous cycle she made very good use of her loan and bought a sewing machine in order to do her works quickly. Now she wants to take a 5th cycle loan with which she will buy more fabrics in order to produce more clothes. She has a deal with the wholesalers to whom she sells the clothes she makes. She is very happy with the loan process and wants to continue taking loans.

loans.name: Naz Bobo

texts.en: Naz Bobo, daughter of M. Karim, was born in 1962 and now lives in District 2 of Kabul, Afghanistan. She is married to M. Saleem and has 3 children. She has a tailoring and knitting business at home. At first it was hard for her family to enjoy a good living because they had financial problems and her business was also very weak, but then she heard about micro financing and she thought about taking a loan to enhance her business. She has finished 4 loan cycles  and now wants to take a 5th cycle. With this money she wants to buy more fabric in order to produce more clothes of a better quality which she can sell in the market for a better price to earn more profit. She says "when you make better clothes with better quality your demand increases at the market which provides a good opportunity to increase your business. I am happy with the loans and looking to go ahead with it in the future."

loans.use: To buy fabrics, a machine, needles, etc.

loans.name: Catarina

texts.en:
My name is Catarina C., and I am a 39-year-old native of Salamanga, Matutuine district, Maputo province. I am a married mother of 4 children, and I attended school up until the 6th grade. I could not continue my studies due to the 16-year civil war that severely affected the Matutuine district. During the civil war my parents took refuge in neighboring South Africa. For two years I worked as a cabinet-maker in a carpenter’s shop and after that I worked as a housemaid for two residences. In 1989 I married a young Mozambique man who at the time also worked in South Africa. With the end of the civil war in 1992 my husband and I decided to return to Mozambique. In 1994, after settling the family in the city of Maputo, I dedicated myself to the sale of diverse products from my residence. My family found it difficult adapting to urban life and in 1995 we decided to move back to my native home of Salamanga, Matutuine district. That same year I began to work on a project of reintegration for those returning from neighboring countries; I worked as a sewing instructor. At project’s end in 1996 I returned to the sale of everyday goods at the local market. In 1998 I rented a small commercial establishment belonging to my brother, and to this day I continue to work there. At this time my husband and I and 4 other employees depend on this business. With the loan I intend to acquire a vehicle to transport diverse cargo to my commercial establishment. This would facilitate our contribution to the increased rent and to the availability of diverse products at accessible prices to more than 100 families residing in the town of Salamanga.

Translated from Portuguese by Marco Alves, Kiva Volunteer.

Catarina C. de 39 anos de idade, Natural de Salamanga, distrito de Matutuíne Província de Maputo, Casada Maritalmente, Mãe de 4 filhos, tendo sido escolarizada até 6ª classe, Não conseguiu continuar mais com os estudos devido a guerra civil dos 16 que afectou severamente o distrito de Matutuíne. Durante a guerra os pais refugiaram-se na vizinha África do Sul em 1985, Por lá começou a trabalhar numa Carpintaria com a Função de marceneira, por um período de Dois Anos e mais tarde veio a trabalhar como empregada Domestica em duas residenciais. Em 1989 Casou-se Maritalmente na Africa do sul com um jovem moçambicano, que na altura se encontrava a trabalhar naquele pais vizinho. Com o fim da Guerra em 1992 decidem com o marido voltar a Moçambique em 1994, Tendo fixado a família na cidade do Maputo e lá dedicava-se a venda de produtos diversos na sua residência, segundo ela, não foram felizes com a realidade urbana assim viram-se obrigados em 1995 a voltar para Salamanga no distrito de Matutuíne, zona de origem. Ainda no mesmo ano começou a trabalhar num projecto de reasentamento dos regressados dos países vizinhos como facilitadora dos cursos de corte e costura. Findo o projecto em 1996 retomou a sua actividade de venda de produtos de primeira necessidade no mercado local. Em 1998 alugou um pequeno estabelecimento comercial do seu irmão, onde continua a trabalhar ate hoje. Neste momento ela e o marido dependem deste negocio com mais outros 4 empregados. Com este empréstimo pretende adquirir uma viatura para transporte de cargas diversas para o estabelecimento comercial sob sua gestão, contribuindo deste modo para aumento da sua renda e disponibilização de produtos diversos a preços acessíveis para mais de 100 famílias residentes na vila de Salamanga.

loans.use: To buy vehicle for supporting her business

loans.name: Armando

texts.en:
My name is Armando M., and I am a 32-year-old father of 4 and a native of Salamanga, Matutuine district, Maputo province. I had few opportunities to attend school due to the 16-year civil war that affected the country; however, I did attend school up until the 4th grade. With schools paralyzed because of the war, I was obligated to immigrate to South Africa in search of work. There I worked at a woodcutting company for four years. After obtaining my driver’s license I began transporting cargo and passengers from Mozambique to South Africa. With the experience I gained I decided to open my own business; I turned to Hluvuku, the only microfinance institution in the area. The vehicle I acquired was a great fit for my work, but months later I was involved in an accident. Since, the vehicle has required restoration.

Armando is a self-employed driver who transports passengers and goods from Mozambique to South Africa and vice-versa. At this time he employs 2 people. With this loan he intends to repair his vehicle and continue with his work—being that this business helps three families survive, including Armando’s. Due to regional characteristics of the area bordering South Africa, many residents immigrate to Mozambique in search of work. Armando’s business’ impact on the community is great because it offers families in Mozambique the use of transportation.

Translated from Portuguese by Marco Alves, Kiva Volunteer.

Armando M. de 32 anos de idade, natural de Salamanga, distrito de Matutuíne Província de Maputo, casado maritalmente e pai de 4 filhos, teve poucas oportunidades de estudos, devido a Guerra civil dos 16 anos que afectou o pais, tendo escolarizado até 4ª classe. Com a paralisação dos estudos foi obrigado emigrar para África do Sul a procura do emprego como costume da zona, onde trabalhou numa empresa de corte de madeira por um período de quatro anos. Depois de ter a carta de condução passou a trabalhar como motorista de transporte de carga e Passageiros no percurso Moçambique e Africa do sul. Com a experiência ganha decide abrir o seu próprio negocio, tendo recorrido a “Hluvuku” como única instituição Micro financeira na zona. A viatura que adquiriu apresentava condições boas para o trabalho, mas meses depois teve acidente, dai a necessidade de reabilitação desta. Trabalha por conta própria como transportador de pessoas e bens de Moçambique – Africa do sul e vice-versa. Neste momento emprega 2 pessoas. Com este empréstimo perspectiva recuperar a viatura e continuar com os trabalho, pois deste negocio sobrevivem três famílias, incluindo a do Armando. Por características da zona que faz fronteira com África do sul, muitos residentes emigram para este pais vizinho a procura de emprego e, como forma de ajudar suas famílias em Moçambique usam estes transportes para o envio de bens, dai o grande impacto desta actividade.

loans.use: To repair his vehicle for transportation

loans.name: Vladimir

texts.en: Vladimir B. is 60 years old and has lived in the village of Pruteni as the town's mestre de limb (literally master of wood) for 40 years.  He uses his skills to make anything someone would need out of wood, whether this consists of using his trade to make different kinds of furniture, doors or window frames he can make it all. Like any Moldovan living in a village he also has many different animals around his house which he uses for his own personal use. He would like a loan to purchase wood and have it milled down so he can use it in his shop to have a steady supply.

loans.use: To purchase wood and have it milled into usable wood to use for his trade as a carpenter.

texts.en: Vasili B. worked at the local community co-operative farm until Moldova regained its independence and collective farming disappeared. Since then he has been working on his private farm and land. Vasili is a widower at 74 years old (his wife passed away about ten years ago) and his one daughter moved to the regional center, located 45 km away, when she got married. Vasili is a very proud man and enjoys working to earn his living. He is eager to purchase seeds and materials to grow different crops this year. He has 2 cows, 4 pigs and 12 sheep, which he keeps on about 2 hectares of land. He would like to take out a loan in order to start planting his land with grains and vegetables.

loans.name: Lucica

texts.en: Lucica J. is a caring and humble grandmother of 63 years old. She spends most of her day looking after her four-year-old granddaughter Madeline while her daughter is at work. When not occupied with Madeline, Lucica is working on her family farm or tending to her 2 pigs and 15 ducks. In the next two months, as the weather becomes warmer, people in Moldova will be starting to plant seeds and Lucica is thinking about growing a variety of vegetables to sell at the local market this year. She plans to produce potatoes, corn, beats, cabbage and more. Lucica would like a loan to purchase some high-quality seeds and to hire someone with a tractor to plow and cultivate her land.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and hire a tractor to plow her land

loans.name: Liliana

texts.en: At 31 years old Liliana O.'s life revolves around taking care of her two young boys (4 and 10 years old) and the family farm by herself. Her husband works in Moscow doing various jobs for six-months at a time and sends back whatever money he can. Close to 25% of Moldova's population is currently working abroad throughout Europe and Russia, and many families rely on remittances for income. Eleana's other source of income from her farm is selling fresh milk at the local market from her 3 cows. The local market is only open for two days a week because the village where she lives, Pruteni, consists of only about 1000 families. Eleana would like a loan to purchase a refrigerator to keep extra milk fresh on the days when the market is closed.

loans.use: To purchase a refrigerator to store excess milk.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en: Maria P.'s saying for how life in the village of Pruteni is, "Viata este gheata" which is a Romanian proverb which literally translates to "Life is like ice" or times are hard and difficult. Maria is 60 years old and she receives a pension from the government, but that consists of only about $40 a month. This is not enough for her to live off of and she still works on her farmstead everyday. Her farm consists of 15 chickens, 1 pig and 5 rabbits and 1 hectare of land. She is requesting a loan to purchase material to build better cages for her animals and to purchase seeds to plant her land this spring.

loans.use: To purchase material to build animal cages and seeds

loans.name: Inna

texts.en: Inna G. is a hard working 32-year-old entrepreneur. Besides from working on her farm she looks after her 1- and 9-year-old boys. Inna's husband is employed as a construction worker for the village of Pruteni where they live. Pruteni lies on the Romanian border and is small, with a population of about 1000 families. There is no running water and only the main road is paved. Inna is a typical Moldovan farmer; she works long days with her bees, 4 cows to produce milk , 30 chickens and ducks and 4 pigs. There is always something for her to do on the farm. She would like a loan to purchase some materials for construction and to make repairs on some of her animal's cages.

loans.use: Working capitol and materials to make repairs on her animal cages.

texts.en:
Meddy Semonobe is 48 years old and married. He has four children. The first born is a girl aged 16 years in senior five, the second is a boy aged 13 years in senior two, the third is a girl of 12 years in primary seven, and the fourth is a boy of 10 years in primary five.

He acquired driving skills in 1981 and has been employed as a driver for 17 years. He would like to lease a saloon car so that he can become self-employed.

The income will help him to meet the school fees for the children. In the future, he plans to save some money so that his wife can start rearing chickens to improve on the family income. He is going to use some of the savings to put a deposit on his lease.

loans.name: Justine

texts.en:
Justine is 32 years old and married. She has six children. The first born is a girl of 14 years in primary six, the second is a boy of 12 years in primary five, the third is a girl of 9 years in primary two, the forth is a boy of 7 years in pre- primary, the fifth is a boy of 3 years and the last one is a boy of 1 year.

Justine has been rearing chickens for the last two years. She is rearing 200 chickens and collects 180 eggs every day. She would like to increase her stock to 500 chickens. She would like to maximize the space that is not in use by stocking more chicken. The bigger the stock, the cheaper the feed and higher the profitability. She would like to expand her business and be able to meet the needs of her children.

loans.use: To increase the stock of chicken from 200 to 500 chicken.

texts.en:
Rita is 32 years old and married with five children. They are aged 14, 12, 10, 5 and 1. She is also supporting two relatives at high school and at the university.

Rita has knitting skills which she acquired from her in-laws in 1998. She would like to acquire a big knitting machine which can make 50 sweaters a day compared to a small one which makes 10 per day. The industrial knitting machine can make bed covers, baby clothes, and stockings and it is fast.

She would like to expand her business by diversifying the products and bid for big contracts in schools and institutions.

Client History: Señora Erlinda has a small stall where she sells sweets, food staples, soft drinks, canned foods, cookies and other cheap and popular products for family consumption. She also sells prepared food (noodle soup). Since her store is close to 2 schools, her soup sales are good. Her store is located in the Tembladerani zone, a neighborhood of the western slope of the city of La Paz. She has three children, all of whom are still her responsibility. They help tend to the store. She is separated from her husband and 51 years old. She has been selling noodle soup in the schools for more than 12 years. Her sales are retail, onsite in her store. She does not have any employees since her children help her.

This is the second time she has applied for a loan from Impro. Her case history in our institution classifies her as Client 0, that is to say with excellent fulfillment of the repayment of her loan. The loan for which she is applying will be used to buy canned foods, sweets, soft drinks and other products as a way to offer more variety in her store.

Her previous credit history with Impro allows her access to this loan, since her experience in her business will bring her the earnings with which to repay the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

Historia del Cliente: La señora Erlinda tiene una pequeña tienda para venta de dulces abarrotes refrescos, conservas y galletas y otros productos populares y baratos para el consumo familiar. También se dedica a la venta de comida (Sopa de Fideo) ya que por estar cerca de dos colegios sus ventas en este rubro son satisfactorias. Su tienda esta ubicado en la zona de Tembladerani (Barrio de la ladera Oeste de la ciudad de La Paz). Tiene tres hijos que están a su cargo quienes le ayudan en la atención de la tienda ya que esta separada de su esposo. Tiene 51 años y trabaja con la venta de sopa de fideo en los colegios más de 12 años. Sus ventas son al detalle, en su tienda y no trabaja con otros empleados ya que sus hijos le ayudan.

Es la segunda vez que solicita un crédito de Impro, su historial en nuestra institución la califica como cliente 0, es decir con cumplimiento excelente en el pago de su obligación. El monto solicitado será destinado para la compra de conservas, abarrotes, dulces, refrescos y otros productos para surtir su tienda.

Su trabajo y antecedentes crediticios con Impro le permiten acceder a este crédito ya que tiene experiencia en su negocio, el cual le da ingresos para cubrir el préstamo.

Clara was born in Monclava in the state of Coahuila. She is married and has two children. Hus husband is a bricklayer. Seeing as his salary wasn't enough to cover the family's basic needs, much less pay for the children's education, Clara decided to open a business one year ago selling clothes to family and friends. At first she sold them on consignment to give her customers time to pay her, but this meant she couldn't recuperate her cost quickly. This is why she started to sell cosmetics as well to try to recuperate her cost faster.

Her customer base has grown slowly but surely. Clara would like to offer a larger selection of products to decrease the time between her investment in the product and profit from its sale. She knows the ins and outs of her business well and would like loan of $250 to purchase cosmetic products to meet the demand of her customers. She will pay back the loan in 4-8 months. Clara thanks all of the people who support her business' growth.

Translated from Spanish by Ari Vilhjalmsson, Kiva Volunteer.

Clara nació en Monclava, Coahuila, esta casada y tiene dos hijos. Su esposo trabaja como albañil y Clara al ver que los ingresos de su esposo no le cubrían los gastos indispensables del hogar y menos para la educación de sus hijos, decidió poner su negocio, el cual empezó hace un año vendiendo ropa entre sus familiares y amigos, inicialmente daba sus productos en consignación para poder darles un tiempo para que sus clientes le paguen y por ello no recuperaba el efectivo invertido rápidamente, por lo que también incursionó en la venta de productos de belleza para compensar el tiempo de la revolvencia de su dinero.

Poco a poco su clientela se ha ido incrementando y al tener una rotación lenta de sus ingresos ella quiere tener mayor cantidad de productos que ofrecer, ya que sabe que en poco tiempo recuperará su inversión ya que sabe muy bien los ciclos de su negocio, por ello Clara esta solicitando un préstamo por US $ 250 para comprar mercadería de los artículos de belleza que ofrece y así satisfacer su demanda, ofreciendo pagar este préstamo en un plazo de 4 a 8 meses. Clara les agradece esta ayuda a todas las personas que la apoyen y la ayuden a crecer en su negocio.

Mrs. Fidencia is a married woman and has four children. Her husband works as an operator of heavy machinery in a local construction company. They live in Monclava, Coahila. Fidencia worked in the past in homes doing cleaning, etc. and her oldest son travelled to the U.S. to work. With what he was able to save, he sent some funds to Fidencia so that she didn't have to work in others' homes and could open her own business, since the reason she works is to support the family income along with her husband. It was with this small amount of capital that Fidencia opened a store with diverse products, particularly for school use, such as notebooks, pencils, etc. Her business has done well, after 9 years in business, and she wants to continue growing it.

Fidencia is requesting a loan for US$250 to be able to purchase merchandise for her business and to be able to offer a greater variety of products to her clients, who are always asking her for new things. She would like to meet her clientele's requests. She is offering to repay the credit in a period of 4 to 8 months and hopes for your help in growing her business.

Translated from Spanish by Naomi Baer, Kiva volunteer.

La Sra. Fidencia es una mujer casada y tiene cuatro hijos, su esposo trabaja como operador de maquinaria pesada en una empresa constructora local, ellos viven en Monclava, Coahuila. Fidencia solía trabajar años atrás en las casas realizando tareas de limpieza, etc. y su hijo mayor viajo a los Estados Unidos de Norte América a trabajar y con lo que pudo ahorrar le envió un capital a Fidencia para que no este trabajando en las casas y abra su propio negocio, ya que el motivo por el cual ella trabaja es apoyar con la economía familiar a su esposo. Fue con ese pequeño capital que Fidencia abrió una tienda de artículos variados especialmente en útiles escolares como cuadernos, lápices, etc. y le ha ido bien con su negocio con el cual ya tiene 9 años y quiere continuar creciendo con el mismo.

Fidencia esta solicitando un préstamo por US $ 250 para comprar mercancía para su negocio y poder ofrecer mayor variedad de productos y novedades a sus clientes, quienes son los que le van pidiendo cosas nuevas y ella quiere mantenerlos, por lo que desea abastecerse de los pedidos de la clientela. Ella ofrece pagar el crédito en un período de 4 a 8 meses y espera de su ayuda para crecer con su negocio.

Margarita is 46 years old and is married with six children. Her husband is a construction worker in Monclava, Coahuila in the north of Mexico. Margarita inherited her business from her father became ill and could no longer run the business. So, Margarita decided to continue on with the business in order to gain income and help her husband. His income is not enough to cover family expenses. And, with the help of Margarita they are moving ahead with their six children.

Margarita is asking for a loan of $250 to buy insumos for her business. She wants this to satisfy her clientele and to grow her business. She will repay this loan in 4 to 8 months. She is grateful to everyone for their help.

Margarita tiene 46 años de edad y esta casada, tiene 6 hijos y su esposo trabaja como obrero en una constructora local, ellos son de Monclava, Coahuila ubicado al norte de México. Ella tiene su negocio como una herencia familiar, su padre era el dueño del negocio, pero se enfermó y no pudo continuar con el mismo, entonces Margarita por la carga familiar que tenía decidió continuar con el negocio para obtener más ingresos y poder ayudar a su esposo, el cual con sus ingresos no podía con los gastos familiares, y así con la ayuda de Margarita sacar adelante a sus 6 hijos.

Margarita esta solicitando un préstamo por US $ 250 para comprar insumos para su negocio, ya que su clientela se ha ido incrementando por lo que ella quisiera poder satisfacer a sus clientes y crecer con el negocio, préstamo que ofrece pagarlo en un período de 4 a 8 meses y les agradece a todas las personas por su apoyo.

María is recently married, and doesn't have any children yet. She became an orphan at an early age, so she was raised by her grandparents who had a mill and so, María learned how to work with it. Three years ago, she was left in charge of the business because her grandparents were elderly and now, the mill is their only source of income. After her marriage, María still had to continue to work the mill because her husband's income was insufficient, and she would like to have a better economic situation. María is already thinking about having her own family and how she would like to give them a good quality of life, just as she would have liked to have when she was a child.

This is why María needs a $475 loan, to keep the mill in shape since it is an old tool in danger of extinction, and she needs to keep it running until she can afford to purchase another one. She will repay the loan within 6 to 12 months and is grateful for your support.

Translated from Spanish by Isabel Tan, a Kiva volunteer.

María esta casada pero no tiene bebes aún ya que recientemente se ha casado. María quedo huérfana a muy temprana edad, entonces fue criada por sus abuelos, quienes tenían un negocio de molino y aprendió a trabajarlo y hace tres años atrás ella se quedo a cargo del negocio por que sus abuelos ya estaban muy mayores y por que era su única fuente de ingresos. Luego de su matrimonio tuvo que continuar con el molino debido a que el ingreso de su esposo es muy poco y quiere poder mejorar su situación económica, pensando ya en el futuro cuando tenga familia y poder darles el sustento que ella hubiera querido siendo niña.

Por ello María esta solicitando un préstamo por US $ 475 para darle mantenimiento a su molino, ya que es un instrumento en extinción por ser muy antiguo y tiene que mantenerse para que más adelante pueda adquirir otro mientras mejora su negocio, ofrece pagar este préstamo en un período de 6 a 12 meses y les agradece su apoyo.

loans.name: Juan Tomas

texts.en:
Juan Tomas supports his family by making bread, pastry dishes, salads and a variety of other dishes, which he either cooks and sells to families in his neighborhood or sells in bulk to local restaurants. His small business is run out of his kitchen at home. This loan will allow him to purchase better supplies for preparing, cooking and restoring food as well as giving him more capital to increase the amount of food he can buy and sell. He currently has to make due using an empty bottle to shape tortillas on a wide ironing board and the families' supplies are used to support the business.

His wife Esther Maria and their three children - Jeraldine, Jehova and Jeremias - live a two-room home in the community of Juan Pablo Duarte. The semi-rural community lies close to the southern coast of the country in the eastern province of San Pedro.

NOTE: Juan Tomas is the president of his Bank of Hope - a group of Esperanza microentrepreneurs in a given community who help each other through the business management and loan repayment process. Juan Tomas and four other members of his solidarity group will be responsible for utilizing and paying back this loan of $750 together. There respective businesses will each receive an equal $150 share of the loan to expand their family businesses.

loans.use: Purchase veggetables, baking ingredients and meat as well as better tools for preparing, cooking and storing food.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

texts.en:
Rimigio has been a rice farmer and a cattle herder his entire life. He has a very limited education, but he is a very hard worker. Although he is over 65 years old, he does not intend to stop working the lands that have provided for him and his family for decades. He feels fortunate to have the opportunity to attain some financing for his lands. He plans to invest in seeds and some pesticides. The loan will help him avoid borrowing from informal lenders who charge way too much and take a large part of the profits he makes from his crops.

The Santa Lucia Communal Bank

Rimigio is part of the newest Communal Banks in the recently developed Mifex Rural Finance Program. All of the members of the Centro Agricola de Santa Lucia Communal Bank are part of an Association of Rice Farmers in Santa Lucia. Their association works cooperatively to help in the commercialization of the product after it has grown. They will use the micro-loans to prepare their lands and cultivate rice on their farms. Because they form part of a communal bank, they are all each others' guarantors for the loan. This means that if for some reason one person in the group cannot fully repay the loan, the other borrowers and the Primero de Agosto Association are responsible for the amount in default. The members of the bank also participate in a program designed to teach and encourage savings among the group. Promoting savings is often forgotten in many micro-finance programs, but Mifex believes that is imperative for the communities we works with to have capital reserved for future investments or unexpected difficulties.

Below is more information about Santa Lucia compiled by Luis Crespo and Robert Edgar of the Mifex team when evaluating the potential of the sector for the Rural Finance Program. Special thanks to Mario Balazantegui who provided expert insight and contributed to the development of the alliances with the local organizations.

Economy of Santa Lucia

Santa Lucia County has a population of about 33,000 people. The sector is fit for rice cultivating because it is not in the lowlands and therefore it is not at risk of flooding. There is also great access to water because of the Daule River, which is accessible to many of the farmers in the area. About 70% of the farmers have basic infrastructure for watering their crops.

Rice production is the main economic activity of the area as about 80% of the people are rice farmers. Almost everyone is either directly or indirectly involved with rice production, as they produce, commercialize or participate in activities that add value to the product. Within the county, there is a small town also named Santa Lucia. The town is filled with many small businesses and it serves as the social and commercial hub of the area.

Rice Farming in Santa Lucia

Most of the people in the Santa Lucia area are small farmers. They produce about 100 sacks of rice per hectare of land. In order to farm they first must prepare the lands by removing weeds and plowing. The farmers then fill an area with water to form what is known as a paddy field, because rice is a very water intensive crop. The rice seeds are either dispersed freely (the process is known as boleo in Spanish) or hand sowed. Once the rice has grown, most farmers rent machinery that helps them gather their production. A risk factor does exist in rice farming because of drought, but in Santa Lucia this is somewhat mitigated by the access to water form the nearby river.

Access to Credit

The biggest struggle in the area has been the lack of credit. Because people do not count on formal financial services, they have turned to loan sharks for financing. They have been affected by expensive lines of credit that exceed 100% interest a year and can be as expensive as 240%. Intermediaries also exploit the farmers because of their outstanding debt. Farmers also lack skills and knowledge to commercialize their products and pay fair prices for their crops.

Loan Use

The loans in this sector will be used to to buy soil, seeds, fertilizer and insecticides. They will also be used to prepare the land prior to farming, to plant the seeds and purchase other materials. The loan repayment schedule is also different from the typical micro-entrepreneur. Because farmers see the profits from their investments 5 or 6 months after making their initial expenditures, Mifex asks them only to pay 50% of the capital in the first 6 months of the loan. The rest of the debt must be paid in the seventh and final month.

loans.name: Sadiah

texts.en: S. is 55 years old. She prepares and sells coconut milk rice and some crackers. She lives by herself since all her children are married and live separately. Sometimes she sells fish as well. She is a member of MBK and wants to have a $50 loan to increase her business by selling fish. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: Preparing and selling coconut milk rice and selling fish

texts.en: W. is a 45-year-old mother with one child, aged 20. She has been selling cooked foods in a small restaurant for 20 years. She usually earns $10 per day. She opens her small restaurant from 5pm – 2am everyday. Her husband, Dakir, is a fisherman. He sells fish in the fish market, earning $2 per day. She is a member of MBK and requests a $50 loan to expand her business. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

J. is 30 years old and is married with two children, ages 7 and 4 years old. She has been running her business selling household goods such as milk, rice, kerosene, cooking oil, etc. for three years. She opens her shop from 7:30am to 7pm. Since she has joined as a member of MBK, her income has increased.  Her husband, Rusdi, is a fish seller, earning $50 per month. She is requesting a $50 loan to complete her shop. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

N. is 36 years old and is married with four children aged 19, 16, 8, and 1. The first three are girls, and the last child is a boy. She sells kerosene, some snacks, and other household goods in a small kiosk. Her husband, Nali, is a fisherman with unfixed income. She can earn $6 per day. She is requesting $50 to expand her business. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

R. is a 46-year-old mother with 4 children. She has been selling cooked food such as fish, chicken, and vegetables for 4 years at her small shop. She very much needs to get a $50 loan to buy more goods, so that she can earn more income. She usually earns $10/day. Her husband, Mucing, has a tailoring business at the house. The income from the tailoring  business is going down now, but it could rise in the festive season. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

Audencio is a rice farmer from the Santa Lucia province. He has been farming rice and raising cattle for about 50 years since he was young. He and his wife Germania have been living on this farm since they were married. They have raised their two kids and fed their family thanks to the fertility of their lands. Their children are all grown up now, but Audencio continues to cultivate rice in order to feed himself and provide additional support to his sons.

The Santa Lucia Communal Bank

All of the members of the Centro Agricola de Santa Lucia Communal Bank are part of an Association of Rice Farmers in Santa Lucia. Special thanks to Mario Balazantegui who provided expert insight and contributed to the development of the alliances with the local organizations.

texts.en: H. K. is a 47-year-old married woman. All of her children are married and live separately. However, one of her children helps her to run the grocery store everyday. She sells household goods, which she buys from Sepatan market nearby. She is a member of MBK and requests a $50 loan to buy more goods. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

S. is 26 years old and is married. She sells stick ice in flavors such as mung bean, milk, and ice cube. She usually earns $1.50 - $2.50 per day. In the summer, she earns up to $7 per day. She also sells fried snacks and delivers them through her neighbors' kiosks. She is a member of MBK and requests a $50 loan. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

S. is a 46-year-old mother with 4 children. She sells some snacks and beverages. She sells them in a small kiosk near a beach. She may earn more income if many fishermen go to the sea. She is a member of MBK and really wants to get a $50 loan to expand her business and purchase more kerosene. She hopes that she can earn more income for her children's education. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

J. is 36 years old and married with three children aged 17, 13 and 8. She sells household goods. Her husband, Uci, does not have fixed income. She could earn $15/day, but the profit is only  $2.50/day. She very much needs to get a $50 loan to make her shop complete and sustainable. She is a member of MBK and is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

D. is 47 years old and married with three children aged 30, 9 and 6. She sells some snacks, beverages, and fruit-flavored blended ice. She once stopped her business due to a shortage of working capital. Now, after being a member of MBK, she has returned to re-open her business. She wants to get a $50 loan to buy beverages like cola, fruit syrups, and some more snacks, and the rest will be spent to buy fishes at the fish market nearby. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

W. is 26 years old and married with 1 child aged 7. She sells kerosene and sometimes sells rice, though in a small scale (13kg per day). Her husband, Kholidin, is a fisherman who goes to the sea once a week depending on the weather. She really hopes to have a $50 loan to buy more kerosene. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

T. is a 28-year-old mother with 3 children aged 10, 6 and 3. The first two are girls, and the last one is a boy. She makes and sells Indonesian salad called “gado-gado”. She used to sell gado-gado using a table, but now she has a small bamboo stall of her own. Her husband passed away 4 years ago, so she is the only one who fights for her and her children’s living. She very much wants to get a $50 loan so that she can earn more income for her children’s education. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

A. is 25 years old and married with one child aged 2. She sells household goods such as rice, cooking oil, and cigarettes. Becoming a member of MBK has been really helpful for her; otherwise, she would have closed her shop. Her husband, Tatang, sells firewood in the market. He can only earn a maximum of $2 per day. She very much needs to get a $50 loan to increase her sales. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

U. is 30 years old and is married with two children. Both are girls. She manages duck livestock. She buys baby ducks and then raises them until they become bigger. She sells duck for $4 each. She can earn more income in the festive seasons. Her husband, Anwar, is a bus driver, earning $4 per day. She very much needs to get a $50 loan to buy more ducks. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

D. is a 29-year-old mother with 2 children aged 9 and 2.  She sells blended ice, snacks, and other household goods at her small kiosk. Before becoming a member of MBK, she used to earn only $2.50/day, and now she earns $4.50/day. Her husband, Empit, is a parking man, earning $1 - $2 per day. She wants to get a $50 loan to buy more goods for her kiosk and is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

U. is 32 years old and married with three children aged 17, 15 and 11. She sells household goods like coffee, instant noodles, and some snacks. She can generate income of $12 per day; with this income, she can supplement her husband's income. She wants to have a $50 loan to expand her business.  Some of the loan will be used to acquire the driver's license for her husband so that he can become a taxi driver, and the rest will be used to buy more goods for her shop. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

T. is 24 years old and married with one child aged 3. She sells fruit-flavored blended ice in front of her house. She usually earns a profit of $1.50 per day. Her husband, Sukron, is a fisherman whose income is unpredictable, ranging between $2 - $3 per day.  She very much needs to have this $50 loan to expand her business. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

M. is 33 years old and married with three children aged 14, 6 and 3. She sells fish crackers and chips. Her husband, Ma’ruf, sells waste and scrap materials. She was very glad to hear about MBK and decided to become a member. She sells the crackers and chips by consigning them at small shops in her village. She can earn $5 - $10/day. Now she can live better than before. She can save some money and send her children to school. She is hoping to have the $50 loan to expand her business. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

I. is a 43-year-old mother with two children aged 18 and 14. She has a small shop selling household goods. She initiated her business by using money from her child. Her husband passed away 6 years ago. She used to borrow from a loan shark, but it put her in deep difficulties. Since joining MBK as a member, she feels glad because the MBK rules are more suitable for her. In the morning, she sells coconut milk rice; in the afternoon, she sells various fried snacks. She wants to have the $50 loan to keep her shop sustainable. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

N. is 36 years old and married with three children aged 17, 15 and 7. The first two are boys, and the last one is a girl. She sells household goods like eggs, rice, etc. She used to borrow some money from a loan shark, and she had to pay $5 per day. It was a real burden for her. After hearing about MBK from her friend, N. has now become a member of MBK and is able to add to her capital. However, she still needs a $50 loan to make her shop complete. She is willing to repay this loan within in a period of 12 months.

T. is a 35-year-old mother with 2 children. She was selling household goods before being a member of MBK. Now she does not have to ask for her husband’s money to run the business since she has received working capital from MBK. Her husband, Tunggon, is a motorcycle taxi driver.  His income is only enough to pay for electricity and other daily needs. She usually earns $4/day, and she hopes to get a $50 loan to buy more goods such as rice, kerosene, and instant noodles. She is willing to repay this loan within in a period of 12 months.

Tarkem is a 35 years old mother with 2 children. She has been selling household goods before being a member of MBK.  Her husband Tunggon  is a motorcycle taxi driver.  His income is only enough for paying electricity and daily needs. She usually earn $4/day  and she expects to get $50 loan to buy more goods such as rice, kerosene and instant noodles. Hopefully she will not have to ask for her husband’s money to run the business anymore after receiving working capital loan from MBK.  She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

R. is a 22-year-old mother with one kid. Before she joined MBK, her husband, Endang, was the only one who worked in her family. Since she has joined MBK as a member, she has started a business by  selling household goods at her small kiosk. She sells snacks, cigarettes, soaps, shampoo, etc. She earns nearly $8 per day. She really wants to get a $50 loan to buy more goods for her kiosk. She is willing to repay this loan in a period of 12 months.

A. is 40 years old and married with 2 daughters. A. sells grilled chickens, and her husband, Adul, sells chicken in the market. She earns $5 per day. She really hopes to get a $50 loan to expand her business, and she intends to spend half of the loan to fund her husband's business. She hopes that, with her income, she can pay for her children's education. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

S. is 27 years old and married with one daughter and two sons. S. has been running her business, which is selling household goods at her small kiosks. Her husband, Rupa, sells rice in the market. She feels happy to become an MBK member because she now can earn $20 instead of $15. She wants to get a $50 loan to buy more household goods and to support her husband's business. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

B. is 42 years old and married with three children aged 16, 14 and 12. She has been running her business for 4 years. She sells vegetables and fried snacks in a small shop. She once had to close her business due to a shortage of capital. After being a member of MBK, she has the chance to re-open her shop. Some of the loan will be used to buy electrical tools since her husband provides electrical and pump services. Since her husband, Marsin, has an unfixed income, the shop is the only livelihood for them.

Carlos and his wife Ingrid have a small farm in Santa Lucia province in Ecuador. Carlos has been living on this land for about 30 years, since it was given to him by his father. Because he only has an elementary education, Carlos wants to provide something more for his 4 year-old son. He relies on the income for his rice farming to feed his family and pay for all the household expenses. He has also been raising cattle for several years as a secondary source of income.

The Santa Lucia Communal Bank

Carlos is part of the newest Communal Banks in the recently developed Mifex Rural Finance Program. All of the members of the Centro Agricola de Santa Lucia Communal Bank are part of an Association of Rice Farmers in Santa Lucia. Their association works cooperatively to help in the commercialization of the product after it has grown. They will use the micro-loans to prepare their lands and cultivate rice on their farms. Because they form part of a communal bank, they are all each others' guarantors for the loan. This means that if for some reason one person in the group cannot fully repay the loan, the other borrowers and the Primero de Agosto Association are responsible for the amount in default. The members of the bank also participate in a program designed to teach and encourage savings among the group. Promoting savings is often forgotten in many micro-finance programs, but Mifex believes that is imperative for the communities we works with to have capital reserved for future investments or unexpected difficulties.

loans.name: Bineta

texts.en:
This is a group loan to be shared by the nine women of the association, led by Bineta B.. In their loan application, the group described their business as follows:

“The village of Mbam is part of the Log zone, which is especially suited to gardening thanks to the high water table that extends to the surface soil. The type of soil and the morphology of the area plead in favor of such a business activity here.

Our objectives are to increase the income of the women of the village, improve the nutrition of village households, contribute to the village’s food security, and acquire access to the latest gardening techniques.

The group leader, a member of the GENSEN committee [note: GENSEN is a voluntary association of rural villages that work together to promote environmentally sustainable community development.], plans to cultivate a vegetable garden of 1.5 hectares, selling the garden’s produce in order to make this investment profitable.

The market for vegetables is lively in the neighboring towns of Passy and Foundiougne, and this provides demand for vegetable cultivation in the region. The supply of vegetables is assured by traders who transport them from one market to another. This project will therefore satisfy the needs of our village. There is a demand for fresh vegetables in the households of our village, but the majority of the demand is found in the markets where traders purchase supplies for urban centers such as Foundiougne and Kaolack.”

Original French business description:

«Contexte du Projet: Le village de Mbam appartient à la partie continentale de la zone du Lôg qui est favorable à l’exploitation maraîchère du fait surtout de la nappe phréatique qui affleure à même le sol. Le type de sol et la morphologie de la zone plaide en faveur d’une telle activité dans la zone.

. Objectifs du Prêt : - Accroître les revenus des femmes membres de l’éco village

- Améliorer la qualité nutritionnelle des ménages du village

- Participer à la sécurité alimentaire du village

- Accéder aux nouvelles techniques de maraîchages

Activités : La promotrice, membre du bureau de GEN SEN compte exploiter un jardin maraîcher de 1hectare et ½ tout en faisant du petit commerce pour rentabiliser son investissement.

Mode de paiement : Le marché des légumes est bien rythmé dans les loumas (Passy et Foundiougne) et favorise l’exploitation maraîchère dans la zone. L’offre de produit maraîcher est l’œuvre des commerçants qui se déplacent d’un louma à un autre. Ainsi le développement du projet va permettre de satisfaire les besoins des populations de l’éco village. La demande de légumes est exprimée par les ménages du village. Mais la grande part se trouve dans les loumas où les banabanas viennent s’approvisionner pour les centres urbaines comme Foundiougne, Kaolack entre autres.»

Background

Senegal is one of the world’s poorest countries, yet its solid democratic tradition and highly developed associational life distinguish it from other countries in its income group. Especially remarkable are Senegal’s networks of rotating savings and credit associations, known as tontines. Commonly organized by groups of twenty to thirty housewives who live in the same village, the tontines provide poor women throughout the country with small loans to finance modest income-generating activities. Repayment rates within these associations are excellent, because they are based on local reputation and personal trust between the members. However, their financial resources are limited to the contributions of their members, frequently subsistence farmers with very little disposable income. This has prevented the traditional tontines from meeting the demand for rural microenterprise loans and restricted their impact on the economic development of their communities. The SEM Fund works to bridge this gap by linking traditional village credit associations with outside sources of finance.

loans.use: Vegetable garden - preparing field, repairing well, purchasing gardening tools, seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Moussa

texts.en:
This is a group loan to be shared by the four members of the Bocc Diom association, led by. In their loan application, the group described their business as follows:

“Located in the rural community of Ngandiouf, at 12km from Pekesse which hosts a big weekly market, the village of Mboul has over 500 inhabitants and lacks means of communication, infrastructures, and road links. Livestock-raising and agriculture are the villagers’ primary means of livelihood.

Our objective is to combat the emigration of villagers to urban areas, and to improve the villagers’ living conditions.

Our business will consist of purchasing cows, raising them, and fattening them in order to resell them in the weekly markets that take place near the village of Mboul.”

Original French business description:

« Contexte : Situé dans la communauté rurale de Ngandiouf, à 12 km de pékésse qui abrite un grand marché hebdomadaire, le village de Mboul compte plus de 500 habitants est reste caractérisé par un manque de moyens de communication, d’infrastructures, de route… Ce pendant, l’élevage est l’agriculture reste les activités les plus favorables des populations.

Objectif : Lutter contre l’exode rural

Améliorer les conditions de vie des populations

Activités : Il s’agit d’acheter des bovins, les élevés en les engraissant puis les revendre dans les marchés hebdomadaires situés au alentours du village de Mboul»

loans.use: Purchasing five young cows, feed, and veterinary care

loans.name: Babacar

texts.en:
This is a group loan to be shared by the ten members of the Dioubo association, led by Babacar S.. In their loan application, the group described their business as follows:

“The Dioubo group is located in the village of Palmarin. Composed of people motivated by a common desire, the Dioubo group aims to unite its members in order to contribute to the development of the abovementioned village. The Dioubo group has adopted the following objectives: to improve the living conditions of its members, to ease the burden of housewives, and to reduce poverty. Our business activities consist of purchasing fresh fish that we will process, dry and sell in the local market and elsewhere in the departement of Mbour.”

Original French business description:

« Le groupement Dioubo est un groupement de l’éco village de Palmarin. Réunissant des gents animés d’une même volonté, le groupement Dioubo se propose d’unir ces membres afin de pouvoir contribuer au développement dudit éco village. Le groupement Dioubo s’est fixé des objectifs suivants : Améliorer les conditions de vie de ces membres Alléger le panier de la ménagère Réduire la pauvreté Activités :Il s’agit d’acheter de la matière (du poisson frais) que l’on va transformer, sécher et le vendre dans le marché local et ailleurs dans le département de Mbour.»
