Especially remarkable are Senegal’s networks of rotating savings and credit associations, which provide the rural poor throughout the country with small loans to finance modest income-generating activities. Repayment rates within these groups are excellent, because they are based on local reputation and personal trust between the members. However, their financial resources are limited to the contributions of their members, frequently subsistence farmers with very little disposable income. This has prevented the traditional associations from meeting the demand for rural microenterprise loans and restricted their impact on the economic development of their communities. The SEM Fund works to bridge this gap by linking traditional village credit associations with outside sources of finance.

loans.use: Purchase of fresh fish, knives and other equipment for producing dried fish

loans.name: Ha

texts.en:
Mrs Ha is 52 years old. Her husband died a long time ago. She has 3 children, 18, 16, and 12. The older two have been working in Ho Chi Minh City but only enough money for living there. They don’t have money to support their family.

Mrs. Ha doesn’t have any land for cultivation. The only way she has to earn a living is to sell sweet soup in the market. She has to support her youngest child, 12 years old, to go to school. She wants to expand this business but she doesn’t have enough money so she needs a loan of $50.

loans.use: To sell sweet soup at the market

texts.en: Mrs Quan is 85 years old. Now, she lives with 2 her niece and nephew. They are 19 and 17 years old. She doesn’t have any land for cultivation. The main income of the family is to purchase betel and areca. She needs US$ 25 for this small business.

loans.name: Doi

texts.en: Mr Doi is 72 years old and his wife is 60. They live with 2 children. One of them is 23 years old and the other is 19 years old. Both of the children are jobless. This family has 2,000 square meters of rice land, and of course the income from this land is not enough for the family. His family does a small business to purchase bananas and they need US$ 50.

loans.use: To purchase bananas at the market.

texts.en: Mrs No is 81 years old. Now she lives with 2 her sons. The oldest son is 38 years old and the other is 31 years old. Both of them are day laborers but are often without work. They don’t have enough money to support their mother so she has to work as well. She has 2,000 square meters of rice land. The income from this small land is not enough for her so she does a small food business. She needs US$ 25 for this business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Teresa Marie Njeri Thuo intends to buy two dairy cows.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Teresiah Wanjiku intends to buy a dairy cow

payments.comment: She paid for the two months at one in august.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Jane Njoki intends to buy a water tank

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Rent more land and buy goats

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Leah Njambi Wanjama intends to buy seeds and seedlings for planting.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Jane Kabura intends to buy fertilizers, seeds and seedlings.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Margaret Wanjiru intends to buy more clothes for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Frasiah Njoki intends to buy a dairy cow.

loans.name: Lien

texts.en:
Mrs Lien and her husband have 9 children between 22 and 3 years of age. Her husband suffers from schizophrenia, therefore he just assists his wife at home. In addition, Khanh, her son, spent $2250 for his cardiac disease. They have no land so 4 of their eldest children stopped going to school. They were very short of money so Anh, Nhat, Toan, Trang had to work as day laborers to earn money to pay for their father and brother’s treatment.

Although they are poor, Mrs Lien tries to support 4 children to go to school. Mrs Lien sells food every the morning at a small market. Mrs Lien received a loan of $50 with no interest and income increased by $1/person/month. Average income is $9/person/month. She repaid the first loan. Now she asks to borrow $50 for her business.

loans.use: Sells food in the morning at small market

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Mary Muthoni Jasan intends to buy a dairy cow.

texts.en:
Mrs Xuan and her husband are old but they have to support themselves because their children are also very poor and they went to another place to earn their living. Mr Thieu is 63 years old and he has a spinal cord problem so he can only help his wife to with house work.

Mrs Xuan sells fish sauce from door to door. She borrowed a loan of $50 with no interest and she repaid this loan already. Her income increased by $1/person/month and her average income is now $12/person/month. Now she asks to borrow a loan of $50.

Miss Ha and her husband have 2 children of 11 and 8. They have 2000 m2 where they built a hut and planted vegetable. Her husband plants vegetables in the dry season and in addition he works as a daily laborer but he can not easily find work. Selling vegetables is thus important for them for increasing their very small income: about $5/person/month.

Ha is a member of a credit group and has already borrowed twice, repaying every week $1- $2 for 45 weeks. This time she wants to borrow $75 to expand her small business and plant vegetables.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Mary Wanjiku intends to buy a dairy cow.

texts.en:
Mrs Tuyet’s husband died and she still helps support 3 children between 24 and 17. Ly, her first, stopped going to school. Her second and third are in grade 12 and 11. She doesn’t have any any land and only has a small hut.

Mrs Tuyet sells pudding and glutinous rice in the morning at a small market. Fortunately, she borrowed a loan of $62 from Mekong Plus and her income increased $3/person/month. Now she asks a loan of $75 for increasing her sales.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Peris Njeri intends to buy another dairy cow.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Isabella Nyambura intends to buy another dairy cow.

loans.name: Haji Mohammad

texts.en: Haji Mohammad is the son of Haji Mohammad Gul.  He was born in 1976 and now lives in District 3 of Kabul. He is married and has a family of nine people. He has a cosmetics shop, which is how he earns his income. At first his business was not doing well because he started his business with little money and only a small stock of clothes and cosmetics. Customers wanted to purchase products that he didn't have available. Therefore, he decided to take a loan. Now he is running his shop more efficiently because he has more products and can better handle his clients' needs.

loans.use: to buy clothes, perfume, etc. for his shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Flora Wanjiku intends to buy a dairy cow.

loans.name: Zarefa

texts.en: Zarefa, daughter of Sakhi Dad, is 38 and married to Sayed Sarwar. Their family contains 5 members. Zarefa is an uneducated lady because her family didn't give her permission to study and after her marriage her financial condition got worse because their sales were low, causing them to have less income. Then she and her husband heard about micro loans and she decided to take loans to improve her business. She is now in her first loan cycle and her business has changed since she took the loan. Now they have more groceries in their shop and her husband buys vegetables from the market, Zarefa cleans them at home, and then they sell them at her husband's shop and earn their income. She is happy with the loan and says she wants to continue taking loans when her first cycle gets accomplished.

loans.use: Buying vegetables ,flour, ghee, etc. for shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Alice Wanjiru Nyambura intends to buy a dairy cow.

texts.en:
Shekiba D/O Mohammad Younis, 38, is married to Mohammad Mahfooz and her family contains 10 members. She is living in District 2 of Kabul City, Afghanistan. Her husband has a grocery and catering shop through which she earns income for her family.

When they started their business they just had a catering shop with limited dishes to offer. Then Shekiba heard about loans from one of her friends and decided to start taking loans.

After the 2nd loan cycle, her husband's business started to develop and besides the catering shop he started a grocery shop as well. She has completed her 4th loan cycle and now she is at her 5th cycle. Now her husband's business is running well and he wants to expand his business by buying more dishes for the catering shop and buying more groceries for the grocery shop.

Thanks to Shekiba that she took loans and assisted her husband in expanding his business.

Zia Gul D/O Rajab, 54, is married to Yaqoob and her family contains 4 members. She is living in District 3 of Kabul City. Zia Gul is not educated because her family didn't want girls to go to school and get an education and she was married at a young age.

She has the business of animal husbandry and she has been doing this business for 15 years. She sells milk, yogurt and cheese at the market and overcomes some of her financial problems. She is at her first loan cycle and has bought another cow with her loan. She is happy with the loan and she says that she hopes to expand her business and help her husband financially.

She wants to go ahead with the loan and after the first cycle, when she borrows a bigger amount, she plans to make a shop where she can sell the dairy products she gets from home.

Juma is a father of 5 kids, two of whom are university students. His wife and children help him in his activity. He has a college degree and he has a goal to help all his kids to get university degrees.

He has experience in livestock for over 22 years. He started as a middleman between individuals who wanted to sell livestock and individuals who wanted to buy it. He used his profit wisely and over a certain period of time collected enough money to raise livestock himself. Currently he has two big cows and two calves. The next loan will be used to buy another two calves. Currently the prices are lower than other periods of the year.

Mukaddas has been engaged in baking bread for over 12 years. She is married and has three children.

After her children became old enough to go to school, the family was in need of additional income. The salary that her husband has earned was not enough. She started baking bread at home in very small volume, mostly for her neighbors. Since her bread was very tasty the demand and number of customers was growing. She invested most of the profit in equipping one of the rooms in her house into a bakery. She also invested her previous loans into that.

Currently she has 3 employees and now she does not bake bread for the market but mainly bakes it by orders for weddings and other events. This way she makes more expensive, high-quality bread and that brings more profit. She will use her next loan to buy a bigger volume of flour.

Zuhro is a resident of Khujand. She sells office supplies in the main market, “Panjshanbe”. She is married and has three kids. She has 7 years of experience in her business.

She considers herself lucky because she has a good business site. From the beginning she had enough capital to buy a big volume of goods and rent space at the most visited market of the town. She became member of the group to start receiving loans from MicroInvest. One member of the group makes trips to wholesale market and the other members work as retail sellers.

Her goal is to buy a shop for her business and stop paying rent. Currently she would like to use her next loan for adding souvenirs to her goods. She noted that very often her customers look for presents and express a need to buy something for their co-workers, manager, etc. Therefore she is sure that there will be good demand for various souvenirs and office supplies given as gifts.

loans.name: Matluba

texts.en:
Matluba and her husband started their business together. Her husband would produce various small goods and Matluba would sell them, storing them in a big case. He would make things like dust pans, cases, and boxes for different uses. She would walk around the market with her case and this was very tiresome.

When they made enough money to rent a trading place, Matluba’s husband started making trips to the wholesale market to purchase different types of goods. Matluba has learned from the other traders in the market about the possibility of receiving loans. She suggested this to her husband and she has been a MicroInvest client for over 2 years.

loans.use: Trip to wholesale market to buy inventory

loans.name: Roberta

texts.en:
Roberta D. lives with her three daughters, Maria Esther, Bartola and Carolina in there home in a small town called Juan Pablo Duarte. Roberta has established her business in this community as having delicious dishes including Yaniqueque (johnnycake) which is a popular and inexpensive Dominican dish, which consists of meat and cheese wrapped in bread and cooked on a griddle. This loan will allow Roberta to go from serving a small number of families in her community, to being able to cook for and sell to the growing number of patrons.

All that Roberta manages to save is going towards a $2,000 operation for her 19-year-old daughter, Maria Esther (pictured center) who has been diagnosed with cancer. Roberta has been managing her small business for more than 10 years and with this loan she will be able to expand and provide better the basic needs of her family.

NOTE: Roberta is one of five microentrepreneurs in her Bank of Hope solidarity group, which have all gone through Esperanza's business training courses and will be accountable to each other for repaying $150 each of this $750 loan together. This group-lending method strengthens social needs in a community and ensures that members cooperate to help one another repay their loans and invest wisely in their business and family.

loans.use: Purchase bread, meat, cheese, vegetables, cooking oil, dishes and materials for her food stand

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Hoang

texts.en:
Hoang is 42 and her husband is 52. They have three children between 16 and 23, and a grandchild. The eldest daughter was divorced when she was pregnant. Both Hoang's husband and son have heart problems. The youngest child is a student at secondary school.

Hoang's family has 2,000 square meters of land where they grow rice. However, the main source of income comes from selling handicraft products made from dry water hyacinths. Their income is about $9 per person/month. Hoang said, "If I have enough capital, I can choose and buy better dry water hyacinths, and purchase the dry water hyacinths before the rainy season". Hoang needs a loan of $75 in order to buy the materials for handicrafts. Hoang promises to repay monthly.

loans.use: To purchase dry water hyacinths before rainy season. She wants to purchase better quality water hyacinths for handicraft products.

loans.name: Dora Elia

texts.en:
Dora is a married woman with three children. They were the reason she started her business eight years ago. He husband is a watchman in a carwash in the cit of Monclava, Coahuila where they are both from. His income was not enough to support the family. Dora is an enterprising woman with the desire to improve the lives of her family. Because of this, she started preparing and selling foods such as tomales, chorizo and hamburgers. Little by little her business grew and her clients requested that she add elotes and games for children on her menu.

Actually, the entire family works in the business to help Dora and because of this, she has increased her clientele. In order to keep the business growing, Dora is asking for a loan of $475 to change the cart used to carry merchandise for a small truck. Dora is preparing to repay this loan in 5 to 10 months and hopes for your help to improve and continue to increase her business.

Dora es una mujer casada y tiene 3 hijos, quienes fueron la razón para empezar con su negocio hace ya ocho años atrás. Su esposo trabaja como vigilante en un auto lavado en la ciudad de Monclava, Coahuila de donde ambos son originarios y sus ingresos no eran suficientes para mantener el sustento de toda su familia, por lo que Dora siendo una mujer emprendedora y con ganas de salir adelante y conociendo el oficio de preparar comida decidió abrir un pequeño puesto de venta de tamales, chorizo y hamburguesas inicialmente y poco a poco en lo que mejoraba su negocio y a pedido de su clientela incremento su menú a la venta de elotes y puso unas maquinitas de juegos para los niños.

Actualmente toda la familia trabaja en el negocio para ayudar a dora y por que se ha incrementado su clientela, por ello para seguir creciendo Dora solicita un préstamo por US $ 475 para cambiar el carrito que tiene para cargar mercancía por una camioneta pequeña. Dora ofrece pagar este préstamo en un período de 5 a 10 meses y espera de su ayuda para poder mejorar y continuar creciendo con su negocio.

loans.use:
Change the vehicle used for sales

cambiar el vehículo que utiliza para la venta

texts.en:
Mr. Agustín is originally from San Luís Potosí. He is 50 years old, and just over 20 years ago he moved to Monterrey along with his family, with the goal of getting ahead and improving the quality of life of his children and wife. For 17 years he has worked selling fruit, vegetables, and legumes. Each morning he travels to Cadereyta, the source of the products he uses to supply other vendors in San Nicolás de los Garza. Mr. Agustín is a very hardworking person with a lot of desire to succeed, and in addition to his commercial work, he also cultivates and sells his own cilantro, beets, spinach, and parsley on a hectare of land which he has on a ranch.

Mr. Agustín has put all his strength into making his business grow, and little by little he has seen the results of considerable gowth in his sales. At present he needs a loan of $550.00 which he will use to invest in more merchandise, alowing him to raise his sales level and generate more income for his family.

(Translated from the Spanish by Naomi Johnson, Kiva volunteer)

loans.name: Dieu

texts.en:
Dieu is 35. Dieu’s husband, Em, is 37. They have two children, ages 12 and 7. The children are students.

They have 3,000 square meters of land where they grow rice. Because of the alkalinity of the soil, their rice production is low. Em has learned how to raise several species of fish. Their income, which comes from both growing rice and aquaculture, is $10 per person/month. Now, they need to receive a loan of $75 for buying young fish and fish food so that they are able to continue and expand the aquaculture business. They will repay monthly.

loans.use: Continue and expand their aquaculture business.

texts.en:
Miss Vinh has 2 children, 13 and 11. She must support them going to school. Toan, her daughter, has chronic bronchitis.

Miss Vinh has a small hut and 2000 m2 of agriculture land. The land is poor and she has no capital to buy fertilizer, so she only can plant cassavas. Last crop she borrowed a loan from a neighbor with no interest. Now she repaid a loan of $32 and her income increased about $3.5/person/month. Her average income is now $13/person/month. She wants a loan of $50 for her planting.
X.

Mrs Thuy’s husband died 6 yeas ago. She has a daughter, Tram. Tram is 14 years old and is in grade 9. Mrs Thuy has no land and no capital. Thuy and her daughter are weak. Thuy suffers from stomach ache and sinusitis. Her daughter caught hepatitis B, so Thuy can’t work as a daily laborer.

She earns money by selling groceries at her hut. She is a good member of the project. She has always repaid her loan on time. She repaid her fifth loan of $60. Now she wants a $100 loan to buy goods in larger quantities and pay cash, which is cheaper, and to raise pigs. Their income increased by 2$/person/month to an average income of 12$/ person/month.

Mrs Ly’s husband has died of cancer and she must support her 4 children between 26 and 7 years old. Two of her children go to the University, one is in grade 11 and the last one is in grade 3.

She don’t have any land and only a small hut. She sells fruits at a small market. Fortunately, she borrowed a loan of $50 from the project. Now she has repaid the loan and her family income increased by $2/person/month to an average of 10$ person/month. She wants a loan of $75 to buy fruits.

loans.name: Alesi

texts.en:
Several years ago, Alesi secured a ST 750 (approximately USD 300) loan from SPBD and used it to open up her small village store.  Alesi has continued to use SPBD loans to expand the supply and variety of goods available to her local customers.  
With a strong history of repayment, Alesi now qualifies for a fourth loan, and she will use these funds to get closer to her dream of owning a fully-stocked grocery and starting up a bakery to sell her home-baked goods.  Alesi says that without the income from her business, she, her husband and their three children could never make ends meet.  Alesi hopes that with the next loan, she can increase her shop sales enough to be able to save weekly for her children’s school fees and supplies.

loans.use: Buy supplies to stock her shop

texts.en:
Zia Gul is a mother of 3 children and lives in district 14 of Kabul, Afghanistan. During the war she lived in a village and from there she learned tailoring. She took a loan from AFSG to buy a new machine, fabric, a table...etc.

She has 5 years' experience in the current business and has found a contractor for herself. She can buy fabric from a shopkeeper and after turning the fabric into clothes, she gives it back to the shopkeeper. Through this process she can make an income and develop her business.

Nurullo started his business over 5 years ago. He is renting a place in open-air market of Chkalovsk. He is married and has three children. The turnover of his business is fast. He started receiving loans three years ago and step-by-step has increased the loan amount from $100 to $1000.

As trading is his only source of income, Nurullo would like to open his own shop, by his house, because working at an open-air market is very difficult, especially in winter time. He plans to use the profit for the reconstruction of his house. After that, he can stay there with his family and one of the rooms he can equip for the shop.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

texts.en: Rosalia has a store which she has owned for about 8 years. She started her business with money she had saved up and the help of a loan from a family member. She sells a variety of different items ranging from rice to snacks. She is requesting the loan because she wants to turn her food market into a general store. She hopes she can begin to offer other products, specifically focusing on school supplies because the school year is set to start soon. This business is a very important part of Rosalia’s household. Although her husband works hard as a door-to-door salesman of goods, Rosalia must rely on her store in order to cover the basic expenses. With the loan she will continue supporting her three kids in their studies and she will also try to make improvements to her home.

Najeba was born in Kabul. She is 35 and lives in district 14 of Kabul in a household of 5.

Najeba has 3 years' experience weaving carpets and can complete one carpet in a month. With the help of her neighbours she took a 1st cycle loan from AFSG to increase her business and bought lots of materials.

She hopes to be a good client for AFSG so she can take more loans to develop her business in the future.

Ameenullah is 27 years old, single, and has a shop in district 6 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He has been working in his current business, selling shoes, for about 3 years. During the Taliban government he sold 2nd hand shoes and after there was peace he opened a new shoe shop to cover his family financially and develop his business.

Ameenullah is happy with the procedure of AFSG, giving loans to people to increase their business. He took a 1st individual loan to design his shop and buy shoes.

loans.name: Abdusalom

texts.en:
Abdusalom has been engaged in trading for 11 years. After middle school, he entered the institute, but could not graduate, so he continued his activity in trading.

Abdusalom had a plan to increase his business, but after marriage it became complicated. Now he has three children and all his profit he spends for family expenses. His current loan request is for renting a shop and increasing his assortment of goods.

loans.use: Rent a shop and purchase inventory

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

texts.en:
Kuland Kor is Indian-Afghan and a citizen of Afghanistan. She lives in district 2 of Kabul, Afghanistan, is 35 years of age and married. She has a tailoring business in her house, sewing clothes for her neighbours and friends. Due to a lack of materials and financial problems she took a loan from AFSG so she could buy a new machine, fabric, a sewing table, thread, etc.

She has 5 years' experience sewing clothes for her husband's shop in the bazaar and she hopes to receive another loan cycle so that she can open a new shop for herself in her alley.

Heran Kor, who is Indian-Afghan and a citizen of Afghanistan, lives in district 2 of Kabul. She is 33 and married.

Heran Kor was taught knitting and embroidery from her grandmother and has continued her business from her. She took a loan to improve her business and buy thread, scarfs and a machine.

She said: 'I have had lots of customers during this period and I believe that I can produce the best quality with new designs in the bazaar. Because of that my clients and neighbours want to buy my work.'

She does not have enough materials - otherwise she would open a shop in her alley - but she hopes to receive a 2nd cycle loan so she can open a new shop.

Gujet Kor is Indian-Afghan and lives in district 2 of Kabul, Afghanistan, in a household of 5. She has a patchwork and net business.

She says: 'During the war I was in Kabul and I learned how to do the trade from my neighbours because at that time there was no other work than these traditional things. Now I'm happy with my business, I can sew one carpet in 45 days and from that I can cover my financial problems and assist my family financially. I took a loan to buy more materials for my business - I always try to produce new designs and the best quality in the bazaar.

Mahila is 27 years old and tries to maintain her family, but she lacks the capital. She is a mother of 2 children and lives in Salyan region, Yenikand village. One day she decided to borrow a loan of $400 to buy 0,1 hectare plot of land in order to overcome a lot of difficulties. Now she is a farmer and has plot of land. She has been in this business for 6 years. Then she borrowed a loan of $600 and bought good quality seedlings. Mahila needs a loan of $800 to buy fertilizer.

Svetlana runs a bustling little fruit stand at the central city market in Nikopol. She has been selling fruit there for three years. After trying her hand at marketing several different products, she found her niche selling a variety of fresh and dried fruits. Through her creativity, hard work, and financial assistance in the form of loans and advice from “Nadiya Ukraine”, her business has developed into a very successful enterprise. Svetlana maintains around $1000 in inventory. In a typical month she will see about $2000 worth of sales with a net income of a little over $1000. Svetlana is requesting a loan for $500 to supplement her available working capital. Her only son, who she raised by herself was, just recently married. Svetlana was able to help financially with the wedding but now needs to rebuild her cash reserves as the busy summer season approaches. She is excited about the possibility of helping her son and daughter-in-law further by opening a second vending location that her daughter-in-law could help run. Eventually, she may be able to operate a successful business of her own.

Світлана активно займається бізнесом з продажу фруктів. Вона володіє невеличким прилавком на центральному ринку м Нікополь. Вона торгує фруктами вже три роки. Спробувавши торгувати іншими товарами, Світлана вирішила все ж таки зупинитися на торгівлі свіжими та сушеними фруктами. Завдяки творчому підходу, наполегливій праці, порадам та фінансовій допомозі від „Надії України”, її бізнес поступово розвинувся та став дуже успішним. У Світлани приблизно 1000 доларів в товарі. Щомісяця її доходи складають приблизно 2000 доларів, чистий прибуток - трохи більше $1000 доларів. Світлана просить про позику в 500 доларів для того, щоб збільшити свій робочий капітал. Її єдиний син, якого вона виховала самостійно, нещодавно одружився. Світлана змогла допомогти з весіллям, але зараз необхідно поповнити свій капітал напередодні активного літнього сезону продажів. Вона дуже хотіла б й надалі допомагати сину та невістці фінансово, і саме для цього планує відкрити другу торгову точку. Невістка Світлани буде допомагати їй з торгівлею, й врешті-решт, можливо, зможе самостійно вести власний бізнес.

Shamo was born in 1980 in Salyan region, Yenikand village. He is single. Shamo started a small business selling clothes for men and women 4 years ago. His diligent, hard work has helped him succeed in his business and maintain a loyal clientele. Now he needs a loan of $1000 to buy clothes and shoes.

loans.name: Valentina

texts.en:
Valentina Lives in the regional center of Floresti but owns a bar in Baranesti, a village on the outskirt of the city. The village of Baranesti is a medium size village with 7000 people, no running water and no gas. Valentina studied accounting in the capitol of Moldova, Chisinau and worked as an accountant for 15 years in a different regional center before deciding to go into business for herself.

Valentina is 40 years old and married. Her husband works in the Army, they have 2 boys ages 18 and 19. She named her bar “Valentina’s” and sells beer and spirits, snacks, and cigarettes. Valentina needs a loan to purchase materials to make repairs and add a terrace on her bar to make it enjoyable for all now that spring is finally here. Valentino has owned this bar for only 9 months and is determined to make it a success.

loans.use: To purchase material to construct a terrace for her bar

texts.en:
Vusala was born in 1977 in Salyan region, Yenikand village. She is married and has 3 children.
In the beginning of her business she borrowed a loan of $600 and bought 2 meaty calves. Now she needs a loan of $1000 to buy 3 meaty calves. She has run this business for 8 years ago.

This 42-year-old man has 7 years experience in this business. Having borrowed a loan of $500, he bought clothes for women. Now he needs a loan of $800 to increase the assortment of his goods.
He lives in Salyan region, Yenikand village, is married, and has 3 children.

This a very kind woman was born in Salyan region, Yenikand village. She is married and has 4 children.
25 years ago she decided to start her own business.
She believes that this business will help her to overcome difficulties and improve her incomes.
Now she needs a loan of $800 to buy a milk cow.

Rovshan is a well known singer in Salyan region, Yenikand village, where he lives with his family. He has 2 children. He has been as a singer for 15 years. All in his village sing his songs.

Having borrowed a loan of $600 he bought a microphone and loudspeaker. Now he needs a loan of $1000 to buy a synthesizer.

Hidjran is 36 years old, lives in Salyan region, Yenikand village, is married and has children. She has run this business for 6 years. In the beginning of her business she borrowed a loan of $500 and bought a pregnant cow. Now she needs a loan of $1000 to buy 2 cows in order to expand her business.

Orkhan has been in this business for 7 years. In the beginning of his business he borrowed a loan of $400 to buy 2 calves. The second time he borrowed a loan of $600 and bought 3 calves. The third time he borrowed a loan of $900 and bought 4 calves.
Now he needs a loan of $1200 to buy 7 calves.

loans.name: Abulfaz

texts.en:
Abulfaz is 44 years old, married, has a child, and lives in the Salyan region, Khaladj village. He has an orchard where he grows vines. He has been engaged in this business with his family for 10 years.
Now he needs a loan of $800 to buy medicines for his orchard.

loans.use: To buy medicines, which are used in orchard

texts.en:
Ziyafat is 37, lives in Salyan region, Yenikand village. He is married and has a child. He is happy with this business. He has 5 years experience in this business. He wants to improve his services to his customers.

Now he needs a loan of $1000 to buy spare parts.

Elman is a father of 5 children. He lives in Salyan region, Yenikand village. He breeds cattle and sheep. He started this business 10 years ago.

With the first loan of $400 he bought 2 calves. Now he needs a loan of $1000 to buy 10 sheep.

Natiga was born in 1963 in Salyan region, Yenikand village. She is married and has a child. She has sold perfumery and decorations for 3 years. In the beginning of her business, she took a loan of $500 and bought perfumery. Now she needs a loan of $1000 to buy perfumery and decorations.

loans.name: Chinh

texts.en: Chinh is 35. Her husband, Khoi, is 32. They have a one year-old daughter. Chinh’s family has 3,000 square meters where they have just begun growing cajupU. trees. It will take three years for the trees to mature and be ready for sale.  In the meantime, Chinh’s husband is a labourer in his village. Chinh has a small grocery store at the gate of Luong Tam primary school where she sells food and school supplies for students. Their total income is $13 per person/month. Chinh needs a loan of $75 so that she will be able to continue selling school supplies for primary students. Chinh will repay monthly.

loans.use: To buy and sell various goods for primary school students.

texts.en:
Alizaman is 28 years old and single. He lives in Salyan region, Yenikand village. He has grown vegetables for 4 years on his own plot of land.
Now he needs a loan of $700 to buy seedlings and fertilizer. You can see in the picture that this man is happy with his business.

Miss Thuy and her husband have 6 children between 17 and 6, all of whom are going to school. Huong is one of Thuy’s children and he has asthma.  They don’t have any land. Mrs Thuy sells fish at the village market and her husband works as a day laborer but he can’t find work easily. She borrowed loan from the project and now she repaid her fourth loan of $60. Their income increased by $2.50/person/month. Their average income is now $8 person/month.

Mubariz has his own store, where he sells foodstuffs. He has run this business for 8 years. In the beginning of his business he borrowed a loan of $600 and built this grocery store. Then he bought foodstuffs and started his business. Before he had difficulties, because he must work a lot of to improve his business. Now he needs a loan of $1000 to buy foodstuffs in order to increase his incomes.

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
Catherine A. is 35 years old and is married with 4 children aged 14, 12, 8, and 2 years. Apart from her children, Catherine also has her younger brother and two other young men that she is training to be tailors who depend on her for shelter, food and clothing.

Catherine got her tailoring skills from her husband who trained her so that she would make money from the tailoring business. Being a keen learner, it took her a short while and within a period of 8 months she became the most sought-after tailor in Kibera. She specializes in ladies' clothes while her husband specializes in male suits.

Two years ago Catherine’s husband got a loan of Ksh 20,000 (USD 285) from a Catholic Church group known as Jikaze Self Help Group, which they used to start off their business that is in operation to date. The husband has since paid back the loan in full.

The business is growing fast, and Catherine now finds that she needs cloth materials to boost her business. Catherine is therefore asking for a loan of USD 150, which will be given in kind to enable her stock her stall. This will greatly increase the number of customers, hence her income will increase too. Catherine promises to train two more people. The repayment period for the loan is 8-14 months.

loans.use: To purchase cloth materials for tailoring

texts.en: Vahid set up his business for 10 years ago. He is a father of 2 children and lives in Salyan region, Yenikand village. He breeds cows and sheep. In the beginning of his business he borrowed a loan of $500 and bought a pregnant cow. Now he needs a loan of $1000 to buy 10 sheep.

Fargana was born in 1968 in Salyan region, Yenikand village. She is married and has 2 children.
She wants to start breeding only Indian hens. This a very kind woman has been in this business for 10 years. Now she needs a loan of $700 to buy 80 Indian hens.

Alikhan was born in 1973 in Salyan region, Yenikand village. He is married and has a child. Alikhan has 5 years experience in this business. He is a very hardworking person. Having borrowed a loan of $400, he bought 10 lambs. Now he needs a loan of $800 to buy 20 lambs.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of a vehicle spray-painting machine

texts.en: Elnur is 24 years old, a single man, and lives in Salyan region, Yenikand village. 3 years ago he decided to start this business. He needs a loan of $700 to buy a milk cow. This is his only sources of income. He wants to improve his business to support the household expenses.

Ilham was born in 1950 in Salyan region. He is married and has 5 children. He has been a vine grower for 20 years. Ilham works very hard for the success of his children. With this business he meets the demands of his family. Now he needs a loan of $500 to buy ferilizer.

42-year-old Adila was born in 1965 in Salyan region, Yenikand village. She is married and has 2 children.
Having borrowed a loan of $600 she bought perfumery and decorations. Now she needs a loan of $1200 to buy  bridal dresses. Adila wants to start selling bridal dresses in order to improve her business.
She has been in this business for 5 years.

Issa lives in the Makangarawe area of Dar es Salaam. He is married with one child. Issa sells used clothes and shoes at Tandika market. The market is well known and famous for selling used clothes.

Issa thanks all the lenders of his first loan with Kiva. With the loan he was able to add shoes in line with clothing sales. Shoe sales have helped him earn more income.

Issa is now requesting a second with Kiva. With this loan he is planning to add a stock of used clothes and shoes. He is expecting higher sales in this coming Easter season. Issa requests a loan of USD 550.

loans.name: Ruska

texts.en: Ruska M. is 47 years old and lives in Silistra. She is married and has two children. Ruska started her own business in 1990. First she was a taxi driver and in 1995 she started her retail business. Ruska M. sells fruits and vegetables on the town cooperative market. She has rented three stalls on the market. Her husband helps her and drives all the products from the store to the city market. The family has their own truck. Ruska M. and her husband need some financial help for their business. They have to make some repairs to their truck and to supply some fuel. The loan amount is $1200.

loans.use: To make some repairs to her truck and to supply some fuel

texts.en: Stoian V. is 48 years old and has had his own business for more than 15 years. He started with agriculture because he and his family have about 200 decares of land but later he started his retail business and now he has two stalls on the city cooperative market. He sells household goods in these stalls together with his wife. Now Stoian V. is applying for a $1200 loan that will be used for working capital.

Dimitar A. is 54 years old. He is single and lives in the village of Srebarna, near Silistra. Dimitar is a technician in education and has worked abroad for many years. Now he works as a guard and during his free time runs a small business. Dimitar has a small workshop for repairing home equipment – refrigerators, cooking ranges and others. His workshop is the only one in the village so he has lots of customers. Dimitar A. needs this $1200 loan for new tools.

Zainabu lives in the Tandika area of Dar es Salaam. She is married with four children. Two are in Primary school and other two in are in secondary school. Zainabu owns a small stall at Tandika market, a famous market in Dar es Salaam for selling used clothes. She sells used clothes for men and women.

Zainabu thanks all the lenders for her first loan with Kiva. With the loan she was able to increase the size of her stall and stock of clothes.

Zainabu is now requesting a second loan with Kiva. With this loan she is planning to add a stock of clothes, improve display facilities and add a new line of locally made “batik” clothes. She is in need of USD 550.

loans.name: Ilia

texts.en: Ilia N. is one of the most popular faces in the town of Silistra. He is 73 years old and keeps a small bar in the town. All his life has passed on the sea. Ilia has been a sailor for more than thirty years. After retiring he opened his little bar in his family house. Now this bar is one of the most famous places in the city and each evening is full of customers. Ilia N. is a widower. His daughter lives in France and he is alone here, so his bar is the only thing that gives him strength. Ilia needs $1200 to make some repairs on his bar because of the coming summer.

loans.use: To make some repairs on his bar

texts.en: Together with her husband Karamfilka V. has been breeding cows for more than 7 years. They both found themselves unemployed and decided to start this farming business. The beginning was hard but now every year Karamfilka and her husband enlarge the capacity of their farm and the number of animals they breed. Now they need $1200 to buy three cows.

loans.name: Tuok

texts.en:
Tuok M. is 46 years old and has 4 children. She is currently supporting three of her children at home, and the oldest at a local University. Her husband is a police officer and earns a monthly salary of $100. Their family lives in a village about 30km south of Phnom Penh.

Tuok M. runs a small restaurant serving pork rice, noodles, and other basic Khmer dishes. She generates $20 of income on an average day, $5 of which is profit. She is using $200 of this loan to increase her basic cooking supplies to serve her growing client-base. She is using the other $200 for basic repairs and additions to the restaurant in an effort to attract even more customers. In the future, Tuok M. hopes to build an extension on the restaurant .

loans.use: Buy supplies for her food shop

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

Dear Kiva Lender,

Great news! Tuok Mun has repaid the Kiva loan early! Kiva and CREDIT MFI make every effort to be as transparent as possible so you can trust the information we give you. In this case, we didn’t let you know that the loan had been repaid at the time. Occasionally, when a loan is repaid early, the payment schedule posted on Kiva doesn’t always match the records of our micro finance partner in Cambodia, CREDIT MFI. As in life, the system doesn’t always run perfectly, but when there is a discrepancy we will alert you as soon as possible so you have all the information about your investment.

On the upside, the issue occurred because the client’s business is so successful! Your loan made that possible. Soon you will see a repayment posted on the client’s profile that is larger than the usual amount. This will end the loan and return the funds to your account. We hope you will choose to loan the repaid funds to another entrepreneur who would a like a chance to grow their business as well. 

If you have any questions, please post them as a comment on this borrowers site and I will be happy to respond. I also encourage you to write comments on the pages of your loan recipients so we can pass along your good wishes to the borrowers.

We sincerely apologize for the oversight and are putting policies in place to make sure that it doesn’t happen again. Thank you for giving poor entrepreneurs in Cambodia a chance at success! 

Best regards,

Sopheap Khiev, Kiva partnership coordinator, Cambodia
Mr. Chan Mach, General Manager, CREDIT MFI, Cambodia

texts.en:
Mrs. Marcela S. Quispe and her husband Mr. Ruben Mendoza Monje, live in their house in the Villa Nuevo Potosi neighborhood on a hillside to the West of La Paz, together with their three minor children, who are still dependent on their parents. Mrs. S. works on her own account buying vegetables from producers and later selling them from her streetside stand in a residential neighborhood in La Paz, while her husband works in public transportation. Mrs. Marcela S. lives in a small dwelling on her property which was built in 2006, and has only three rooms (kitchen, dining room and two bedrooms), which needs a bathroom. The loan she is requesting is intended for the construction of such a family bathroom, (toilet, wash basin and shower), with which the quality of their live will be substantially improved, along with the families health. She has been helped by loans in five previous occasions which were used for the purchase of merchandise, and her record demonstrates her regular payments of her obligations.

Translated from Spanish by Dwight Davis, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Marcela Sánchez Quispe y su esposo el señor Rubén Mendoza Monje, viven en su casa en la zona Villa Nuevo Potosí, ladera oeste de la ciudad de La Paz, junto a sus tres hijos los cuales son menores de edad y aun dependientes de sus padres. La señora Sánchez trabaja por cuenta propia, comprando legumbres adquiridas desde los productores y que luego vende en la zona residencial de La Paz, en un puesto de venta en la calle, y su esposo trabaja en el transporte publico. La señora Marcela vive en una pequeña vivienda de su propiedad construida el año 2006 y que solo cuenta con tres dependencias (cocina-comedor y dos dormitorios), por lo que se hace necesaria la construcción de un baño. El crédito solicitado será destinado a la construcción de un baño familiar (inodoro, lavamanos y ducha) con lo que mejoraran sustancialmente su calidad de vida, así como las condiciones de higiene de la familia. La señora anteriormente ya fue beneficiada por créditos en cinco ocasiones anteriores para la compra de mercadería, y su historial muestra regularidad en el cumplimiento del pago de sus obligaciones.

loans.name: Thon

texts.en:
Thon P. is 32 years old and is a mother of 3. She and her husband (pictured here because she was busy working when we visited) work on their small plantation growing a variety of vegetables. One of her daughters works in a garment factory in the outskirts of Phnom Penh and earns $50-80 per month. They are also raising 2 pigs which they will eventually sell in the local market.

With this loan, Thon P. will increase the size of her plantation and continue to raise her pigs for additional income when they mature. This loan will help Thon P. to increase her standard of living, and she is confident that her income will grow with this new resource.

In the future, Thon P. dreams of saving enough money to build a new home for her children.

loans.use: Expanding plantation and buying food to raise pig

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Titin

texts.en: T. is a 28 year-old mother with three children ages 10, 6 and 3. The first two are girls and the last one is a boy. T. makes and sells an Indonesian salad called “gado-gado”. She used to sell gado-gado using just a table, but now owns a small bamboo stall. Her husband passed away 4 years ago, and now she is the only breadwinner for herself and her children. She is raising three kids on her own, and would like to help pay for their college from the business's income.  She really wants greatly expand her business and earn more income for her children’s education.

loans.use: Help expand business of selling an Indonesian salad called gado-gado.

texts.en: A. is 25 years old and is married with a two year-old child. She sells household goods, such as rice, cooking oil,and cigarettes from her small kiosks. Becoming a member of MBK has been really helpful, otherwise she would have been forced to close her shop. Her husband, Tatang, sells firewood in the market. He earns not much more than $2 per day. She now needs a significantly larger loan to help increase the stock of inventory in her store.

Dewi is a 29 year-old mother with 2 children, ages 9 and 2. She sells blended ice, snacks and other household goods. She used to earn only $2.50/day, but after joining MBK and obtaining a loan to increase her inventory, she hopes to be able to increase her earning to $4.50/day. Her husband, Empit, is a parking man, earning $1 - $2 per day. Dewi wants to buy more household goods inventory for her small shop.

U. is 30 years old and is married with two children. Both children are girls. She manages duck livestock. She buys baby ducks and then raises them until they mature and are ready to be slaughtered. She sells each duck for $4. She can earn more income during the holiday seasons, when demand is higher. Her husband, Anwar, is a bus driver, earning $4 per day. She needs a bigger loan to buy more ducklings for her farm.

loans.name: Upini

texts.en: Upini is 32 years old and is married with three children ages 17, 15 and 11. She sells household goods like coffee, instant noodles, snacks etc. Some of the loan will be used to acquire the driving license for her husband so he can become a taxi driver. She can generate an income of $12 per day and uses her income to help her husband. She needs a bigger loan to expand her business.

loans.use: Upini sells household goods, and needs a loan to help expand her business and help her husband become a taxi driver.

texts.en:
E. is 45 years old with 3 daughters. E. makes and sells fish crackers and dried salted fish to help with her family's financial situation. Her husband, Munawar, sells fish in the market. E. requests a $50 loan from MBK, part of which will be used for her business and the rest for her husband's business. With this loan, hopefully E. can increase her daily income from Rp. 100,000 to Rp. 120,000.

Translated from bahasa Indonesia by Kresna Hartandi, Kiva Volunteer.

E. berusia 45 tahun mempunyai 3 orang anak perempuan. Membuat kerupuk ikan dan ikan asin dan kemudian menjualnya adalah usaha yang dilakukan E. untuk membantu perekonomian keluarganya. Suaminya Munawar menjual ikan di pasar. E. memperoleh pinjaman dari MBK sebesar $50, yang sebagian digunakan untuk membuat kerupuk dan sebagian lagi digunakan untuk usaha suaminya. Dengan memperoleh pinjaman dari MBK, E. dapat meningkatkan pendapatannya dari Rp. 100,000 menjadi Rp. 120,000 per harinya.

loans.name: Rita

texts.en:
R. is 22 year old with one daughter. Before becoming MBK member, R. could only rely on her husband to earn money for the family. R. is hoping that by becoming an MBK member she can help her family's finances by opening a small kiosk that sells various snacks, cigarettes, soap, medicines, shampoo, etc. She will use the $50 loan from MBK to open her kiosk. R. can now earn Rp. 75,000 (about $7.50) per day. She hopes to obtain larger loan to expand her kiosk.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Kresna Hartandi, Kiva Volunteer.

R. berusia 22 tahun mempunyai satu orang anak perempuan. Sebelum menjadi anggota MBK, R. hanya mengandalkan suaminya sebagai tulang punggung keluarganya, namun setelah menjadi anggota MBK, R. dapat membantu perekonomian keluarganya dengan membuka warung kecil yang menjual anek makanan kecil, rokok, sabun, obat-obatan, shampoo dll. Pinjaman dari MBK sebesar $50 seluruhnya digunakan untuk membuka warungnya. Sekarang R. dapat memperoleh penghasilan Rp. 75,000 per hari. Dia berharap dapat memperoleh pinjaman yang lebih besar lagi sehingga dapat memperbesar warungnya.

loans.use: To purchase materials for her store

texts.en:
A. is 40 years old and has two daughters. A. owns a grilled chicken business, while her husband sells live chickens in the market. The $50 loan from MBK will be used partly for her grilled chicken stall and the rest for her husband's business. Hopefully with Rp. 50,000 (about $5) earnings, A. can help with her family's financial situation and pay for her daughters' tuition expenses. A. needs a larger loan to expand her grilled chicken business.

Translated from bahasa Indonesia by Kresna Hartandi, Kiva Volunteer.

A. berusia 40 tahun dan mempunyai 2 orang anak perempuan. A. mempunyai usaha berjualan ayam bakar, sedangkan suaminya Adul berjualan ayam hidup di pasar. Oleh karena itu pinjaman yang diterima dari MBK sebesar $50, sebagian digunakan untuk usaha ayam bakar dan sebagian lagi untuk usahanya suaminya. Dengan pendapatan Rp. 50,000, A. dapat membantu perekonomian keluarganya dan dapat membayar biaya sekolah anaknya. A. memerlukan pinjaman yang lebih besar lagi agar dapat mengembangkan usaha ayam bakarnya.

S. is 27 years old with a daughter and two sons. S. has owned her small kiosk for a while. Hopefully with the $50 loan she will obtain from MBK, she can buy more inventory for her kiosk. Part of the loan will be used by Rupa, her husband, to sell rice in the market. S. hopes that with the MBK loan, she can increase her earnings from Rp. 150,000 (about $15) to Rp. 200,000 (about $20).

Translated from bahasa Indonesia by Kresna Hartandi, Kiva Volunteer.

S. berusia 27 tahun dan mempunyai seorang anak perempuan dan dua orang anak laki-laki. S. telah mempunyai warung sejak lama dan dengan pinjaman yang diterima dari MBK sebesar $50, dia dapat membeli barang-barang keperluan warungnya lebih banyak lagi. Dari pinjaman yang diterima, sebagian diberikan kepada suaminya Rupa untuk berdagang beras di pasar. S. merasa senang menjadi anggota MBK karena kini penghasilannya juga meningkat dari sebelumnya Rp. 150,000 menjadi Rp. 200,000.

R. is a 46 year-old mother of four children. She has been selling cooked food such as fish, chicken, and vegetables at her small shop for about 4 years.

She urgently needs to get a loan to buy more raw goods, so that she can produce and earn more. At this time, she usually earns $10/day. Her husband, Mucing, has a sewing business at the house. His income is currently declining, but it may increase in the holiday season.

loans.use: Purchase more raw material to increase her business

texts.en: S. is a 46 year-old mother of four children. She sells some snacks and beverages and she plans to use the loan to buy kerosene to sell. She could earn more income if many fisherman go to the sea. She hopes that she can earn more income for her childrens' education.

loans.use: Buy kerosene to expand her business

texts.en:
T. is a 35 year old mother of two children. She has been selling household goods since before becoming a member of MBK. She usually earns $4/day and now she does not have to ask for her husband’s money to run the business anymore as she has her own working capital from MBK.

She expects to get more loans to buy more goods such as rice, kerosene and instant noodles. Her husband, Tunggon, is a motorcycle taxi driver. His income is only enough for paying electricity and daily needs.

loans.use: Purchase capital to expand her business

texts.en: H. K. is a 47 year-old married woman. All her children are married and live separately from her. However, one of her children helps her to run the grocery store everyday. She sells household goods which she buys from the Sepatan market. She wants to use the loan to buy more goods.

loans.use: Buy goods to expand her business

loans.name: Titin

texts.en: Titin is a 28 year old mother of three children aged 10, 6 and 3. The first two are girls and the youngest is a boy. She makes and sells Indonesian salad called “gado-gado”. She used to sell gado-gado using a table but now she has a small bamboo stall of her own. Her husband passed away 4 years ago, therefore she is the only one who fights for her and her children’s living. She very much wants to earn more income for her children’s education and to expand her business.

loans.use: Buy capital to expand her business

texts.en: W. is 26 years old and is married with one child, aged 7. She sells kerosene and sometimes sells a small amount of rice (13kg per day). Her husband, Kholidin, is a fisherman who goes to the sea once a week depending on the weather. She really hopes to have a larger loan to buy more kerosene.

loans.use: Purchase kerosene to expand her business

loans.name: Wiwi

texts.en: Wiwi is  26 years old, and is married with one child aged 7. She sells kerosene and sometimes sells small quantities of rice (13kg per day). Her husband, Kholidin, is a fisherman who goes to the sea once a week depending on the weather. She really hopes to have a larger loan to buy more kerosene.

loans.use: Purchase capital to expand her business

texts.en: D. is 47 years old and is married with three children aged 30, 9 and 6. She sells some snacks, beverages, ice and also fish. She once stopped her business due to a shortage of working capital. Now, after being a member of MBK, she has re-opened her business. She spends some of her loan to buy beverages like cola, fruit syrups and some snacks and the rest is spent buying fish at the fish market. She really wants to expand her business in the future when she gets bigger loan.

loans.use: Purchase capital to expand her business

texts.en: A. is 25 years old and is married with one child, aged 2. She sells household goods such as rice, cooking oil, and cigarettes. Becoming a member of MBK is really helpful, since she would otherwise have had to close her shop. Her husband, Tatang, sells firewood in the market. He earns no more than $2 per day. She very much needs a bigger loan to increase her selling.

loans.use: Purchase capital to expand her business

texts.en: J. is 30 years old and is married with two children, aged 7 and 4. She has had her business of buying and selling household goods such as milk, rice, kerosene, and cooking oil, for 3 years. She opens her shop from 7.30 to 19.00. She spent the loan from MBK to add more goods to her shop, therefore her income increased. Her husband, Rusdi, is a fish seller earning $50 per month. She hopes to have bigger loan in the future.

loans.use: Purchase capital to expand her business

loans.name: Seng

texts.en:
Seng S. runs a small grocery store on the outskirts of Phnom Penh. She buys food and drinks at the local market, then she sells them at her shop which is more conveniently located in the village.

S. is able to generate between $10 and $20 of revenue from her grocery store on the average day. Additionally, S. grows vegetables which she uses to feed her family. She and her husband are raising five cows which they eventually plan to sell at the market.

S. wants to use this loan to buy an oven so that she can further expand her grocery business. She is the mother of three children and hopes that soon she will be able to send them to school.

loans.use: To expand her grocery store and to feed her cows

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Thuy

texts.en:
Thuy was born in 1972, and her husband, Muoi, was born in 1960. They have two children, ages 12 and 15. Both children have had to leave school because the family does not have enough money to continue paying for their education. The family is so poor that they have been given a small home by the government.

Thuy is a day laborer. She gathers waste materials at her local market. Her husband sells scrap and waste materials to the local recycling company. The family's income is only $11 per person/month. Thuy wants to get a loan of $75 so that her husband can begin purchasing larger amounts of scrap material which he can sell to the recycling company. They feel that they are helping their community and the environment through their recycling efforts. They will repay monthly.

loans.use: To purchase scrap material which can be sold to a local recycling company.

loans.name: Nga

texts.en: T. is 34 years old and her daughter, an 8th grade student,  is 14.  T. has no husband.  They live with Thuys mother.  The three of them live together in a small house, only 40m2.  T. has been running a small food shop at her local market for the past two years.  She sells rice and hu tieu--a chinese noodle soup.  Her income is only $10 per person/month.  With a loan of $75 she will be able to expand her food shop.  She wants to buy more tables and chairs and begin selling a wider range of foods.  She will repay monthly.

loans.use: To expand a small food shop at the local market

loans.name: Orn

texts.en:
Orn O. and her husband run a small business in the city of Phnom Penh. Together, they plant crops which they use to help support themselves and their three children. Additionally, O. and her husband raise pigs which they will soon sell to a butcher at the local market. As another source of income, O. sews clothes for friends and neighbors in her village.

As O. and her husband make just enough money to break even, they often rely on their daughter--who works at a nearby factory--for support. O. plans to use this loan to help feed their pigs and also to repair their house.

loans.use: To raise pigs and to repair house

payments.comment:
Dear Kiva Lender,

Great news! Orn Oeun has repaid the Kiva loan early! Kiva and CREDIT MFI make every effort to be as transparent as possible so you can trust the information we give you. In this case, we didn’t let you know that the loan had been repaid at the time. Occasionally, when a loan is repaid early, the payment schedule posted on Kiva doesn’t always match the records of our micro finance partner in Cambodia, CREDIT MFI. As in life, the system doesn’t always run perfectly, but when there is a discrepancy we will alert you as soon as possible so you have all the information about your investment.

On the upside, the issue occurred because the client’s business is so successful! Your loan made that possible. Soon you will see a repayment posted on the client’s profile that is larger than the usual amount. This will end the loan and return the funds to your account. We hope you will choose to loan the repaid funds to another entrepreneur who would a like a chance to grow their business as well. 

If you have any questions, please post them as a comment on this borrowers site and I will be happy to respond. I also encourage you to write comments on the pages of your loan recipients so we can pass along your good wishes to the borrowers.

We sincerely apologize for the oversight and are putting policies in place to make sure that it doesn’t happen again. Thank you for giving poor entrepreneurs in Cambodia a chance at success! 

Best regards,

Sopheap Khiev, Kiva partnership coordinator, Cambodia
Mr. Chan Mach, General Manager, CREDIT MFI, Cambodia

loans.name: Tep

texts.en:
Tep P. is 37 years old and has a shop in Phnom Penh where she cooks and sells food (mostly noodles and meatballs) to people in her village. P. also grows vegetables and raises chickens and ducks. Her business activity usually results in a daily profit between $2.50 and $4.00. Her husband is a carpenter and can make about $2.00 on any given day.

In the future, P. hopes to expand her business activity and open an additional shop where she would sell hardware. Also, P. would like to buy a sewing machine to open a clothes shop. With this loan, however, P. plans to buy a machine to help harvest her crops.

loans.use: Expand her food business and harvest crops

texts.en:
Tha S. is 26 years old and sells fish at a stall at the Olympic Market in Phnom Penh. On the side, she and her husband raise cows and pigs which they plan to sell to a butcher at the market in the near future. The couple is able to generate between $10 and $20 of income per day, but average only $5 profit each day. After deducting the cost of renting her stall at the market ($20/month), S. and her husband struggle to support their two young children.

With this loan, S. hopes to buy her stall at the market outright so that she no longer has to pay the fee to rent it. Additionally, she hopes to expand her animal-raising business.

Rehema lives in Tandika, the Temeke District of Dar es Salaam. She is married with five children. Rehema sells charcoal in a store located in her family house. She has been in this business for over eight years now.

Rehema thanks all lenders for her first loan with Kiva. With the loan she was able to open another charcoal store in the next street and employ an assistant

Rehema is now requesting a second loan with Kiva. With this loan she is planning to add a stock of charcoal for the two stores. The two stores are doing good business for she has employed herself and an assistant. Dar es Salaam is now in the rainy season, so having enough stock is an advantage for her. USD 750 will facilitate her stocking requirements.

C. is married with three children. He lives in Kitunda area of Dar es Salaam. The area is well known for residents engaging themselves in animal keeping.

C. sells animal feeds to these animal keepers.He buys by-products of maize,cotton,palm kernels, sunflowers and other cereals and packs them in bags of 5kgs and 10 kgs ready for resale. C. also keeps chickens, of which his wife is in charge.

C. thanks all lenders for his first loan with Kiva. With the loan he was able to add a stock of animal feeds and he bought a bicycle which he uses to ferry animal feeds to his customers.

C. is now requesting a second loan with Kiva. With this loan he is planning to add a stock of animal feeds and a flock of chickens. The chicken hut needs to be expanded to accommodate 200 birds from the 100 birds normally kept. The plan needs a capital funding of USD 750.

Salum is married with one child. He lives in Vituka in the Temeke District of Dar es Salam. Salum sells maize in retail. He buys the maize in large quantities from nearby regions, stocks it and resells it in retail.

Salum thanks all lenders for his first loan with Kiva. He is now requesting a second loan. With this loan he is planning to improve his business by having enough stock of maize, especially in the beginning of the rainy season. Because roads to up country are not easily passable during the rainy season, it is better to have enough stock now.

Extra stock demands some more packaging materials, carriage costs and storage costs. To make his plan work Salum is in need of USD 750.

Omari lives in the Kitunda area of Dar es Salaam.He is married with two children. He owns a retail shop near his residence. The shop sells different consumable items, especially food items, rice in particular.

Omari thanks all lenders for his first loan with Kiva. With the loan he was able to increase the stock of rice and other food items.

Omari is now requesting a second loan with Kiva. With this loan he is planning to open another shop in the next street. From his own savings he managed to pay rental fees for the shop premises. What he needs now is a working capital to fill the shelves of a new shop. He is in need of USD 750.
